i'm not the biggest champion of self-driving cars, but i think way too much of the conversation is sensational rather than inquisitive and informative. it's easy enough to find a few silly situations to ridicule, but i don't think the news reporting we are getting will age very well. at the rate things are developing, it seems likely that self-driving cars will be safer than the average human driver relatively soon. now that they are considered safe enough to operate and learn in a live environment, they will evolve even faster. we shouldn't let these companies get away with murder, but it doesn't seem like they are trying to. seems to me like they are just trying to do their best in a somewhat dismissive (and sometimes outright hostile) media environment. progress is inevitable, and in the case of self-driving cars, perhaps mostly for the better. at least if we take it seriously enough to prepare for it. there will probably not be much need for human drivers in the future, and it's important no to stick our heads in the sand and pretend that isn't going to happen.

if we look at the history of automation though, the most likely way this will play out is something like this:

*yesterday:* _what do you mean self-driving cars? don't be silly! that is total science fiction and will never actually happen._
*today:* _look at all those silly autonomous cars! they can only drive as well as a human 99% of the time, and sometimes they stop for no apparent reason. how hilarious._
*tomorrow:* _we have to stop all these self-driving cars that are so massively outperforming human drivers! we can't compete and are losing our jobs! this isn't fair!_

they should make separate infrastructure for self driving cars for maximum efficiency and safety. a fellow driver might not understand how self driving cars think or work or what it might pull off on public roads. we could see separate infrastructure especially for self driving trucks carrying freight and goods in the near future. don't put self driving cars with human drivers, its best if its separated. it also depends on where you are using it in, a downtown area will be much harder to use vs a normal suburb with mostly straight roads.

there are a few points that i‚Äôd like to make:
1.  human beings are incapable of doing much of anything without training.  
2.  what level of training has the average driver received over the years they have driven?
       bad habits occur.  yet the average driver gets tested once at a basic level over a lifetime.
       expecting them to be proficient drivers is unrealistic.
3.  technology requires good design, construction, and regular maintenance.  the more advanced the
      technology, the more critical the maintenance becomes.  yet, the average car doesn‚Äôt get regular oil changes.
      how can we expect self-driving cars to be properly maintained?
4.  due to the increased level of computer technology in semi-trucks, truckstops and shops find it difficult to
      find qualified technicians to work on these vehicles.  what will it be like with millions of self-driving
     cars on the road.
5.  these test vehicles are not representative of the production vehicles of the future.  corporations will take dangerous shortcuts and use substandard parts to minimize costs and maximize profits.  how reliable will be that technology?
6.  it would appear that the data is being manipulated through minimal driver training to achieve the poor human driver results.  would you want to have an operation from a doctor with the same level of training?

i would encourage everyone to be skeptical of any data or claims coming from either side of the self-driving car debate.  rather, look at the big picture and decide for yourself.

@@nik-do1wd ok so tesla has 2 systems.
the one you used is called autopilot, and is a traffic-aware lane assist and cruise control system intended for highway use.
the one that's relevant for the future of self driving is called fsd, or "full self-driving" and is in closed beta. you need to live in the us, and you need to apply to get to use it. (for now)

fsd is a different beast entirely. it's a machine learning based self-driving ai designed to work on any road, anywhere.

if you want a taste of what it does, check out a youtube channel called ai drivr. he does videos where it drives him around in challenging areas with dense traffic, narrow roads and complex intersections.

while the concept of autonomous is good, it won‚Äôt solve traffic. city planners refer to induced demand whenever a freeway, like the 28 lane katy freeway, adds new lanes. new lanes equals more drivers on the road since there is more supply, and you get more traffic since the extra capacity meant for the 20 cars in the freeway before expansion will now be filled up by new cars. 

also, say the autonomous cars of the future to go around like a network and there is 0 breaks or anything. how would you cross the city if you were a pedestrian? it‚Äôs like a deer running on a road, near impossible.

i'm on board with this, kind of, as it is sad to think we may not own cars and be able to drive them ourselves in the future, but it is so devastating losing so many lives to road accidents. i generally think that we should limit our car use so that we rely on trains (and buses?) a lot more and then have driverless cars only for the last mile in cities and also for rural areas (where it would be inefficient to run a regular public transport service to a small community where lots of seats would be wasted). we need to move away from the notion that everybody can have a car each - it's incredibly inefficient in production and maintenance costs (and emissions) and wastes a hell of a lot of space, even though it is sad to imagine a future where we can't own our own car. we especially need to move away from designing our cities to cater for everyone to get around by car, and instead consider cities where the only modes of transport are public and cycling, therefore eliminating a great deal of accidents and crime.

yes, i believe the waymo cars do exactly that- they look at how much cars wander around (and beyond) their lane and presume that car has a higher variability of movement and account for it i.e. they behave more cautiously. i don't *think* they look inside cars to see if the driver is distracted, but i have a vague sense that with cyclists and pedestrians they do identify which way the human is looking and include that in their predictions about likely future paths.

one of the big differences i see is that the waymo cars are *patient*. if they think a car is likely to wander into their lane, they'll just keep holding back until it's safe to pass. as a human, i will eventually get grumpy and accelerate past while glaring at the driver.

i completely disagree. i am not a fan of driverless cars:

1. benefit for a very small array of very big companies.
developing driverless cars is a technical and most of all a remakable it challenge.
only a small group of very big companies are going for it, we see that the challenge is so great that even some already big companies team up for this development.
the manpower and burnt funds for the development are massive.
the very few companies coming through with a safe driverless solution expect of course accordingly extraordinary profilts and return on their investment.

2. who will be able to use a driverless car in the forseeable future? 
driverless cars will, given a successful development, operate in areas with high population density and clients who are prepared to pay the extra buck for this.
the vast majority of the polulation in a few "rich" countries won't be able to use driverless cars, not to mention the rest of the world.

3. who is losing out?
basically there is no difference between a uber car , a taxi, or a driverless car. you book the lift,  pick up , and something brings you to a certain destination.
but the driver job feeds a lot of people, as a full time or part time driver. these guys work hard and pay taxes (as we know that this is not so certain for the biggest companies). 
the dream of the driverless car developers is of course to replace all other individual transport services.
in polarized societies it is already difficult for "less qualified" people to find work, this is the wrong direction! no society needs more unskilled workers. 
another burden for taxpayers? or more people on the streets?

4. reasonable investment for future generations?
in times of increasing extreme climate events, droughts, other man-made desasters, still huge areas without proper education,  and many more problems, 
it would have been wiser to use the billions of dollars already burnt for driverless car development for education, environment and sustainable energy research and deployment instead.

only the tech hype "cool what this can!" does not justify mindless wase of money in gigantic proportions for show, shareholder value, and some possible benefits for a small group of "cool" people in "cool" places.

the clip you showed of someone arguing an edge case where it encourages people not to wear helmets is not invalidated by its rareness. people don't act based on statistics. if they did, we wouldn't be in the mess we're in right now in 2021. we don't need to stop pushing autonomous vehicles forward for this helmet question (the system is nowhere near capable enough of accurately identifying safety equipment and making decisions based on it so it's not a relevant question) but other questions do need to be addressed.

let me give you a perspective that is a bit more worrying to me. twice in the past few months we've seen a huge swath of the internet go offline for a few hours when a major cloud host went down. first google, then amazon. it's been a wakeup call to some that we've overcentralized our online infrastructure, but others are ignoring it...because of course they are. just last week we had a zero day where all apache servers (the most common web server software). the concern with automated driving is it potentially creates a very deadly single point of failure. i don't see that happening with waymo's current fleet as they are largely autonomous and, importantly, nowhere near the most common vehicle on the road. but let's fast forward to when an automated system controlling vehicles is as common as toyota vehicles. there are three major issues that need to be clearly addressed before many of us will trust allowing them to grow towards that point.
1. does it stop working if some external service goes offline - gps, internet, a server in toyota's basement, whatever. obviously, given a certain country it's being developed in, it can currently stand to be without internet for a while because american internet, but we can't get ourselves dependent on a transportation technology that stops functioning entirely if an online service goes down. a smartbulb that won't work anymore because the server discontinued is a small inconvenience, but if ford goes under and shuts off servers their vehicles depend on, that can result in a lot of slow and painful deaths. 
2. can the fleet be compromised. the talk of cars that communicate with each other sounds great...unless you work in computing. then it sounds like someone forgot bad people exist. that sort of inter-connectivity is like handing the nuclear codes to anyone who figures out or is told how to send commands to those cars. if someone figured out how to send the command to accelerate over that communications system (which, even if the communications system doesn't convey commands is still possible) then millions could die within hours.
3. can individual cars be attacked. for a while, many banks and credit card companies were putting wireless chips in cards and insisting it was "safe". security experts demonstrated a small loop of wire that could fit in someone's pocket, along with a small control device could pull all the needed information off the cards from a distance and reproduce it on demand. now those chips aren't in most cards anymore. a few manufacturers are desperately claiming theirs are "safe" but few are gullible enough to believe them now. this one is going to have to be demonstrated, not merely assured. something like letting a few hacker conventions have at the vehicle on a closed course where they won't have any qualms about making it do things that would otherwise be lethal. this one is more for avoiding unnecessary roadblocks. we don't want car manufacturers to get gunshy about automated software like banks did with the card chips. yes, you can get people to quickly trust the car to drive, but it can just as quickly generate distrust and outrage if one person gets killed because a malicious individual tricked the vehicle into doing something wrong. you would also need to test against large scale shutdown attacks such as saturating an area with the right frequency of light that the lidar is using or painting something with a material that scatters or absorbs that light.

saving lives is a good goal, but if you leave the door open to losing more lives, or if you rush forward so fast that you stumble and slow down the process, then you've done a disservice. being better than what we have now isn't good enough. we have to work through the ramifications of it to avoid unintended consequences.

many years ago, people worked out that putting lead in gasoline would solve a major problem. and an entire generation got lead poisoning from that. unintended consequences can be disastrous beyond your wildest dreams, especially for something as ubiquitous as transportation. we need this technology to succeed, not be held back by early failures that could have been anticipated if we had listened to the people we thought were just naysayers.

great video.   this is a long one but i have a lot of thoughts on this subject.   here's my four biggest concerns with autonomous cars at the moment:

1) there's a big difference between self-landing aircraft and self-driving cars.   planes are tightly controlled, tightly regulated, thoroughly maintained and kept under secure conditions (generally).   the same is true of the airports.   the runway, weather conditions, optimal glide slope, height of surrounding terrain etc are all known quantities, and the pilots should be warned ahead of time in case of any exceptions or technical faults.   runways are regularly patrolled and aircraft are inspected before each and every flight.  nobody is going to walk onto a runway with a paint roller and draw some new markings on and divert the aircraft to a new location.   a massive unexpected pothole should not appear without someone noticing.   the pilot would have dozens of miles of advanced warning in case ils is not functional.   nobody should be able to smear some grease onto a camera lens or cut a cable while the plane is stopped in traffic and render the landing systems inoperative.  finally, except for the final few seconds before touchdown, a landing takes place over many minutes and miles, and there is a large period of time to detect misalignment or deal with checklists, and go-around if something is wrong.   a pedestrian steps out from behind a parked car?   you've had a split-second to deal with that.

2) how does the car respond to a technical or mechanical fault?   i'm sure it can be easily programmed to deal with faulty sensors/cameras, but what happens when it detects a slight pull to the left, the brakes start to fade down a long hill, or the engine loses power right before pulling out of a junction?   it could easily be programmed to respond to sub-par performance and limp to safety, but i imagine it'll be some years before the car "making a funny noise" is easily detected.   something as simple as a nail in a tyre could be clearly heard and felt by a human, but would be very difficult for software to reliably detect.

3) where does the burden of responsibility lie, if the vehicle has no driver?   a man drives a car into a pedestrian and kills them, because they sneezed and closed their eyes.    one person potentially to blame, one person to prosecute, one person to punish or feel the guilt.    what happens when the car fails to correctly anticipate a situation, or a software update with an unforeseen bug gets pushed out and all of a sudden thousands of cars suddenly stop detecting pedestrians on crossings correctly and you have 500 fatalities in one day.   do you chalk that up to experience, or charge the "negligent" programmer with 500 manslaughters?

in a world where cars are driverless, you could argue that any and all accidents not caused by road conditions are therefore the programmers responsibility.   then you have a situation where it's nearly impossible for them to exist with a perfect safety record, as they will inevitably make some mistakes or not predict some outcomes, so the developers will have to decide whether they can deal with having a few deaths on their conscience, because the statistics suggest it's likely more people would have died if they'd been driving themselves.

4) what happens in an accident if the car is driving empty?   it doesn't full on smash into someone but maybe its action causes another car to crash into someone else, or it clips a child, not enough to cause a loud impact that would class as a noticeable g-force, but it makes a thump any human would know to investigate and would see an injured toddler.    the car doesn't know the difference between that and catching a stray branch or a pothole, does it carry on to its next destination leaving the child in the street or the crashed cars to fend for themselves?   essentially automated hit and run.

in summary:  in public transit systems like air, rail, and sea, there is so few obstacles and variables and they are typically travelling via well maintained and well regulated and inspected routes and vehicles.   issues should be detected before they cause fatalities and all the routes they are travelling on are known and controlled.   the open road is far too variable to account for all possibilities in advance, unless this is restricted to purely and simply well maintained cities and highways, with clear road markings and known routes.   even then, it's not perfect.   so do we settle for on average fewer people dying, but some people will die needlessly?   i'm not suggesting we never have driverless cars, but they need to be at the level where they are so rigorously tested and tightly controlled and regulated with equally tightly controlled and regulated roads and highways that it would take a near perfect society with perfect roads where programmers can predict every possible outcome before it could happen.   in my view, anyway.

a driverless car would be ideal for my visually impaired girlfriend as it would solve her problem of short distance to medium distance travel. a lot of her time is wasted going to the start point of public transport, switching public transport and from end point to final destination. however, this technology is only viable if it's truly autonomous 100% of the time. that means not only must it be able to navigate all kinds of obstacles like roadworks and accidents, but also all kinds of weather. (rain still seems to be a problem for waymo sensory systems.) a lot of road infrastructure has to be either changed or augmented to accommodate these vehicles. for example traffic regulatory systems (traffic lights, speed signs, etc) need some way of communicating with the vehicle as well as communication between vehicles. also for better or worse a lot of legislation has to be done. (it took literally centuries to come up with road rules.) and we as a society have to accept that small and major accidents will happen. i also imagine that "car ownership" is going to be an issue. it looks that tesla bets that cars will be still owned by the majority of individuals, while the rest (alphabet, ford, etc) assumes that a "car as a service" is the more likely outcome. i can imagine that we might not even have individual cars in the future, but something that is a hybrid between car, bus and train.
so from an engineering point of view i understand your enthusiasm. in the end it's not the engineering but timing and luck which determines the success of autonomous vehicles.

to be transparent- i have been very excited about the development of driverless cars for future use. i think a component that is not highlighted enough in discussion of this development, is how beneficial it would be for those who suffer from accessibility issues. 
in much environmentalism work, people fail to think about how efforts to be eco-conscious can affect those with disabilities. i'm not saying to throw environmental activism out the window, i'm just saying that people with disabilities need to be considered in conversations about making the world a better place, as very frequently decisions are made without having them at the table.
with that in mind, i've had a very open mind to driverless cars where some may have not (with the hope that they could be as eco-friendly as possible), understanding that public transport has not been as effective at being a handicap-friendly service as pick up and drop off services have (at least, in my city in canada, that's the case).
so i was prepped to really be on board with this video. 
i was expecting to hear pros and cons, and caveats to paired with exciting new considerations from a variety of experts.
i ultimately did not feel like we were got that.

i so want to be able to get around as freely as others-  not being dependent on a person being available to take me somewhere is a big deal. what's bigger however, is knowing that l would be safe, and if there isn't an accurate understanding of where things are at in development, people with disabilities may decide to make use of driverless cars before it's advisable.
it should be fine to tell both sides of the story, because if driverless cars are going to thrive, they're going to have stand up under scrutiny. 
this video only gave voice to the company whose product is being highlighted- it makes sense that they would be inclined to paint a positive picture of their product, but where is the point of view of any external specialists in this field?
that fact there were no alternative points of view examined or external specialists featured, made this feel incredibly biased. i imagine you could have even brought in a specialist who reinforced your position, but even that wasn't done.
to present, seemingly, that there are just no downsides or dangers to driverless cars at this point seems a little premature. the majority of other companies in the space do not seem ready to launch their own driverless cars yet- this seems to indicate that there still must be a lot of fine-tuning that is needed.

please consider that when you paint such a positive picture of something, people may believe it and then act upon it. a person with a disability may not have the proper autonomy to help themselves out if a driverless car acts in error, but if they believe they won't have to, they may decide to be some of the earliest users of this service. this may put some very vulnerable people in a dangerous position.

i wanted to know accurately what kind of hope we have for this type of technology, and it did not feel like i received an unbiased report of that here. it really is a shame, because i love this channel, and i believe that you believe what you have shared here. i just also feel that you may have challenged it more if you didn't have to answer to the sponsors of this video. people tend to look at scientists and science channels as the tellers of truth, and i want to believe that that is the case more often than not. 
in situations like this, i start to get n worried.

i've been saying this since high school 10 years ago. fully automated cars are the future and when they become more common than driver operated cars, road fatality numbers are going to plummet.

so... has the programming behind these cars solved the "trolley problem"? how does it react in an unavoidable collision where it has multiple options of what to hit? can it weigh the moral choice between hitting a granny on one side of the street trying to cross or a group of schoolkids who suddenly came out from in-between two parked cars, unseen, and now too close to be avoidable in time? what about when a deer pops out from out of nowhere right in front of you in a narrow, wooded road through the forest? does it understand that if you have no other options, hitting a deer is still better than swerving into a tree causing a complete deadstop (which has much higher risk of injury or death to the vehicle occupants than hitting the deer which has some "give" to it and won't slam a vehicle to a deadstop instantly?) etc. 

it also needs proper testing in varying rain and snow conditions, something testing in this area of arizona doesn't give much of (particularly the snow part.) and even if it understands normal rainy conditions, can it tell that a wet road *with fallen leaves on it* is *way* more slippery than a normal wet/rainy road? trying to brake on a wet road with leaves is like ice, if you've ever had the misfortune to need to stop suddenly under conditions like that.

i'm all for more autonomous vehicles as long as the full scope of safety features is fully behind it. i just don't want shortsighted statistics under limited conditions getting people to go "oh well, current stats say accidents would go way down with this, so we need more of them everywhere now!" i'm totally for the autonomous vehicle future, as long as we don't rush it too fast and test even under extraordinarily rare circumstances, in an incredibly varied number of environments where you will get very different weather and road conditions, has an incredible amount of awareness and contingencies built into it for unavoidable accident scenarios to take the least damaging/injurious/lethal/etc course of action in a split-second, etc. like i said at the start, it needs to solve the "trolley problem" in a way that is going to be universally acceptable to nearly everyone in society. if it kills a kid instead of a deer someday, you're going to have not only a tragedy there, but a *huge* outcry, outrage, and a resulting *huge* setback to acceptable and adoptance of this technology (so i really do say this as someone who'd like to see this technology improved and used more, not a hater trying to claim it'll supposedly never be good enough, like some you see out there criticizing this stuff.)

@@flubnub266 "just move" is kind of a callous response, especially when, as the other guy kinda stated, the people most impacted by the decision to increase driving license regulations would be those who really couldn't do anything about it. if you're rich enough, you might be able to uber to work, or you might have a support structure capable of driving you, you might have a carpool. but if you don't have any of those things, you're likely not well enough off to move, especially if your job's just been taken away thanks to the fact that you can't drive anymore. in most of north america, driving isn't an option, it's a necessity, and for many people, moving isn't really a possibility, especially if they have to move outside of the us, to another country. you've basically told them to move to like, mexico, because getting an eu citizenship or a work visa is really pretty hard.
the real unspoken solution to this problem is just to redesign the city to have less cars, because cars inherently, and in large numbers, as they are, are going to be lethal, especially with how north american roads are intrinsically designed, with multiple points of conflict, and design elements that are at odds with one another, relative to, say, german design. for example, large, multi lane roads, which is something primarily used for ferrying heavy traffic and amounts of cars, intersecting with smaller roads, via turn lanes, or turnouts, which necessitates frequent lane changes. that creates multiple points of conflict, and is a design that's at odds with itself, it attempts to serve multiple contradictory functions. north american roads often have to be designed this way simply to accommodate the fact that everyone has to have cars. this is a scaling issue, too, you can look at parts of denmark or the netherlands, and they use cars infrequently, compared to, say, urban france, which is better than germany, and then germany is better than north america.

the potential for raw stats to add an impact to this video was missed. still an awesome video and i loved seeing everything in it though.

i wrote a paper in july 2018 titled, "what is society's understanding of the impact/benefits of autonomous vehicles?"
in 2020 there was 1.37 fatalities per 100 million vehicle miles traveled by humans. that translates to about 100 people per day, or 36,000+ people per year.
when i wrote the paper in 2018, there had been a total of 4 fatalities with autonomous vehicles in the usa (3 by tesla and 1 by uber) with over 5 billion autonomous miles driven. that makes 0.08 fatalities per 100,000,000 miles driven.

*deaths per 100,000,000 miles driven:*
humans: 1.37 (36,000+ deaths a year)
autonomous driving: 0.08 (4 deaths total)

you pick which one you think is safer. ;) i'll hard pressed to give up driving, because, well, i love it. but the stats don't lie, even if people don't believe them.

all this information is public on the united states department of transportation.

the titled should be "why you want the top 1% to have driverless cars, 'cuz, let's face it, the rest of us couldn't afford it."  poor people aren't going to have driverless cars until there are used driverless cars that are cheap enough, so about 10 years from now.  you don't want driverless cars on the road with old parts, software develops bugs and gets slower, sensors stop working accurately, hardware is no longer supported by software updates.  basically, a 10 year old driverless car will be considerably less safe than it was when it rolled off the production line.  unless you make new self-driving cars that cost the same as used cars, they are never going to take over.  the solution is not to make older cars illegal, that would steal the livelihood of hundreds of millions of people that can't afford to pay more than $3,000 for a car.  even if upgrading a car to be driverless costed $3,000 it would still mean asking a poor person to pay twice what they can afford to have a car.

less than a third of the cars on the road are newer than 5 years, and less than 1% of cars are older than 25 years.  that means that if every single new car made were driverless this year, it would take 5 years before a third of the cars were driverless, and 25 years before 99% of cars are driverless.  it is very unlikely every new car will ever be driverless, so this skews even further into the future.  retrofitting older cars to be driverless could work much faster, but because of the vastly different abilities of older cars there would be an enormous amount of errors causing accidents.

driverless cars are a rich persons toy.  at least for the next 3 decades, assuming we start making every single new car driverless.

the reason why we have as many cars as we do today started because germany came up with a way to make cars cheap enough for everyone to have.  then america decided that being able to move a large amount of people and military equipment very quickly on a highway network would greatly increase the ability for the nation to defend itself.  however, that decision was made when there was a draft, any adult male between 18 and 64 would be required to join a war.  now the military doesn't expect everyone in the country to be ready to fight a war.  we have many fewer soldiers and they are specially trained.  we transport them in the air or on enormous boats.  we do not fight wars with hundreds of millions of people anymore.  even if world war iii started tomorrow, it would probably be over before the government decided to enlist every adult male between 18 and 64.  simply put, the original purpose of cars is no longer relevant.  cars are an outdated technology for a problem that no longer exists.  we are not fighting a massive war, and even if we were, we wouldn't be able to rely on the highways.  there would be traffic jams the entire country over and the only chance of the military using the highways would be if they had a giant bulldozer weighing 30 tons that can push people out of the way so they can transport the necessary equipment to where it is needed.  that would never happen.  ever.  it is more likely they would use massive boats going up and down the coast moving things, or thousands of cargo planes, or underground pipelines, or mega-trains.  we don't need cars.

  the question isn't whether or not they should be driverless, it is whether or not we should invent something new to replace them altogether while we still have the resources to do it.  cars are not now, nor ever will be, economically or environmentally sustainable.  every single car is less then 15% efficient at turning fuel into moving a human.  you weigh less than 200 lbs, but your car weighs 3500 lbs.  even if your car were "%100 efficient", it is still moving 3,500 lbs of car to move less than 200 lbs of person.  that means that 87.5% of the energy being used by the car is being used just to move itself, and only 12.5% to move you.  the whole concept of cars is too inefficient to take seriously in the 21st century.

  as an example of a system to replace cars.  imagine a remote-controlled shopping cart that weighed 100 lbs and could carry 50 lbs of groceries.  a person has to get a "remote-control vehicle driver's license".  a car has to move 3,500 lbs to move 50 lbs of groceries.  that is 70 lbs of car moved for every lb of groceries.  this would move 3 lbs for every lb of groceries.  that is 23 times less energy.  a typical car costs $25,000.  a remote-controlled shopping cart could cost less than $3,000.  you wouldn't even need to own one, you could rent one from the grocery store for $5 a trip.  that is $260 dollars a year for the transportation of groceries, assuming you shop once a week.  compare that to the cost of insurance and fuel that is usually over $1,000 a year.

  this is just one example of how we could replace the car.  there are many like this that would save the environment.  if we are going to be pouring billions of dollars into changing cars, we should at least be doing it in such a way that improves the world.  this delivery shopping cart idea is 20 times as energy efficient as electric cars, and probably 40 times as energy efficient as gas cars.  not only that, it would cost less than switching to self driving cars, and is better at the one thing that self-driving cars can claim.

  the only thing going for self-driving cars is that they are safer, but no matter how safe they drive they can't compete with a vehicle that weighs 20x less than them.  not only that, if everyone used these smart-carts for all their shopping, they wouldn't even be out in a car in the first place.  the number of accidents would plummet, and the number of accidents with people actually in the cars would also plummet.  the number of injuries and death would go so much lower that driverless cars couldn't even compete with it.  not to mention the money lost in accidents would go so low that insurance for these things would be very cheap.  you would no longer need to pay out $35,000 in damages, at worst just $3,000 in damages and $200 for the shopping that was lost.  no hospital visits.  even if a normal car was in an accident with one of these, the chances of them being hurt when their 3,500 lb car hit a 100 lb shopping cart is so low that even the insurance for regular cars would go way, way down.

  we need to think outside the car.  there are way better options.

your concerns are warranted, for the data we have.
however, we don't have the data of the future, and predictions are becoming more and more unlikely, even with larger numbers, especially with something as volatile as an economy. unemployment rates have fluctuated throughout history due to many factors including technological advancements.
humans are very adaptable, and there is a low chance that a complete overhaul of car automation will happen at once, giving ex-employees of companies that decided to adopt autos the chance to plan. the average age of truck drivers, for example, is around 45-55, with an average retirement age of just over 60. there is a shortage on the rise, actually, for many reasons other than automated vehicles.
i'm not an expert, but i think you should be eased by the fact that everything is unpredictable, and not all people that rely on the driver industry need to worry about it much for at least 5-10 years.
as for prospective employments, i really can't say much. if the cost of driving is lowered for companies due to automation, the profit margins skyrocket. expansion is inevitable and more and more jobs still in need are going to be in demand.
i think you know as you read this how complicated it gets, and you'll soon need to take into factors such as population growth, the matthew principle and other public health issues. 
i agree with your concerns, but we can never be too sure of the impact, less so of the aftermath, and we have no idea what is in store for the future of employment opportunities, not only in the usa, but other countries, especially developing ones, which in my experience have to be very innovative.

great video.  i always laugh when i hear people's hugely optimistic vision of the future.  at the end of this video he sees a future where the rise of autonomous vehicles will mean less traffic, fewer cars on the road and more green spaces.  lol  history has shown that human beings always seem to expand to fill their capacity.  what i mean by this is if we figure out some way to do something more efficiently, that doesn't mean we will have less of it - the exact opposite!  we will get more of it.  if riding in a car becomes simpler, cheaper and more efficient then most likely we will do more riding in cars.  the number of trips that people take will increase.  i hardly think that we will reduce our road system and build more green spaces.  if we can improve our cars so that they can more easily navigate a 4 way intersection then we will just increase the number of cars on the road until we get traffic jams even with autonomous vehicles.  :)

first off, this is a great video. i agree a lot of people are too skeptical about driverless taxis, and that this a great future to achieve. do i think they'll be ready soon? i'm not qualified to answer that.

however, derek seems too biased towards this. not because of the sponsorship, but him personally. i can see why he's such a big fan, though that makes some of his arguments over-optimistic. yes, elevators and trains have become driverless, but they have limited movement options and traffic. planes have traffic, but most of those are controlled by professional companies who regulate the movement trajectories. cars, on the other hand, are driven by rando people who have no obligation but to themselves. so way more chaotic. a reason why there are more car accidents than plane accidents.

now that would seem to imply that replacing humans with machines should improve safety. if it is a dominant replacement (like over 90%), i would agree. but people are selfish; many of them enjoy the feel of driving themselves and so they'll demand their right to be able to drive cars even if driverless cars are an option. and in many places, the biggest problems for driving is not the environment but the other human drivers. if they all followed the rules like machines, we would be swell. but they don't, sometimes unintentionally.

yes, driverless cars have accumulated more driving experience than any human driver. but that doesn't make them a better driver. because part of driving is predicting how the other drivers will react ... which means you need a mental model of how humans think. that is something which comes free with most humans and allows them to be better drivers despite the much lower experience.

@@justintro good point, i should have googled that first. turns out lidar is 905 - 1550 nm, and infrared is considered 700 nm - 1 mm (visible light being 400 - 700 nm). i know some animals rely on infrared to hunt prey. i also know that my phone camera sensor picks up some of the infrared from my tv remote. so i feel pretty strongly that there will be some impact of filling the streets with these cars. it might still be worth the cost in the end, i just want to make sure the people working on this technology have at least considered the impact.

well, the self-driving car technology is more challenging than self-driving airplanes or drones. still, airplanes are not flying without pilots today! do you wonder why? beside technical issues there are serious ethical and legal issues. for example, if a collision is inevitable what crash scenario/path shall self-driving car take? drive into the concrete wall and kill passengers or drive into the buss stop and kill crowd of people but saving lives of the passengers? who will be legally responsible and pay monetary compensation to the victims? the manufacturer of the self-driving algorithms, the insurance company or the passengers/owner of the car? in addition, it has been shown already that it is not worth to pump each self-driving car with very expensive high-tech sophisticated equipment (which you need to maintain, make software updates and replace often its hardware). it is simply too expensive to have lidars, stereo imaging, radio radars, acustical etc sensors as well as powerful computer to process data. the sensors do not work good in bad weather conditions like snowing, raining, dusty environment etc. instead, the society shall invest into a smart cities and highways infrastructure where each vehicle on the road will get real-time information about the traffic situation on the road and all vehicle (self-driving or not) will get this information via 5g high speed network and the traffic will be routed optimally and in a safe way. that will also allow to reduce emissions, avoid traffic jams and potential accidents much more efficiently. this is the future.
self-driving cars are not the future, because cars are simply not the future. this is just a delusional attempt at keeping our unsustainable way of living.

i love the video and the vehicle is really impressive, but to me, it's not really about the tech, as a software engineer i can say that a.i. designers and data scientists know what they're doing - my issue is with the human drivers. do you trust them around your autonomous vehicle? and then we have companies like tesla who are out-right lying about their autonomous driving modes ... it becomes a huge mess of ethics and business priorities. who is liable if your autonomous vehicle kills someone? what if it gets hacked? what if auto vehicles get a virus which causes them to do stupid things on the road? the vehicles become a huge black box where most normal people (users or owners) wouldn't even know how to fix them and or take care of them. so, naturally, you have to totally eliminate vehicle ownership ... you must then rely on companies like waymo to transport all humans ... and now you've restricted your freedom of travel to the routes they have programmed.... you see where this is going? unfortunately, for autonomous vehicles to truly work well, human vehicle ownership needs to go, therefore putting all your freedom of movement in the hands of a.i. and companies making such a.i. ... this isn't a good thing, humans are already losing crucial life-sustaining skills with every new generation, how many people do you know can hunt or farm their own food today? exactly ... so now, with auto-driving we are further reducing the general human ability by taking away common motor-skills from people... i just don't feel like this will lead to a better future. motor-skills, situational awareness, decision making under pressure and so on are important human skills to have and maintain - even if they lead to some accidents in the process, you will never be 100% safe. imho, your airplane comparison is really invalid, planes aren't really worried about "traffic" or pedestrians, and, pilots go through insane (and very expensive) training and licensing before they can engage the "auto pilot" button on a 747. unfortunately, the roads aren't as empty as the skies...  finally, if covid taught us anything, it is that the government is in absolute control over our travels and whereabouts, should we really give them even more power, i.e. the ability to disable all autonomous cars with a click of a button when they don't want us to move around like they grounded all airplanes and stopped travel between nations with the stroke of a pen? as someone working in autonomous driving, i really enjoyed this video! however, the reason why i believe they can't yet replace humans is the human factor.

the neural networks that are trained to analyze the surrounding of the car are still very much biased. they might be trained well for specific suburbs and or highway, but places with different layout and/or surroundings will throw them off. try going on a street through a forest. also, has the car been trained on deer? it might detect there's *something* but if it can't detect what it is, it might react poorer than a human, cause it hasn't been trained for this (and believe me, it almost certainly is not trained for this).

besides, often the data used to train these neural networks have bias against people of color or disabled people. so a wheelchair might be falsely detected as a bench and the car assumes the person is sitting still instead of going over the road. these things are due to how humans select the data for the training and looking into preventing these biases is a topic many companies only start to look into.

and i'm not even going into "attacks" on autonomous cars. ever saw the give of a car trapped in a circle of salt cause it things that's a "do not cross" lane marking? or the autonomous car driving behind a truck that transports traffic lights and the car detects them as traffic lights installed on the road? edge cases for sure, but human would know how to react, they would recognize that this is nonsense. having an autonomous cars decide these situations are nonsense and ignoring sensor data seems like a bad idea as well tho.

i do absolutely think autonomous cars should become the norm. but being exposed to all the problems they still have if your not in a very specific, almost controlled environment, i don't believe that this future is close yet. though i do hope to be proven wrong! we're working on it ;)

i can fully accept that driverless cars are safe and the technology is sound. but holy crap, where's the fun? i love driving. how sad and grey and mundane will the world be if everyone is riding around in these things? sure the roads would be safer but i'm happy to take the increased risk for the measure of control driving allows me. unfortunately we seem to be heading toward a future where personal agency is all but a thing of the past. how sad.

this channel has good production value, and i am very impressed with your knowledge, but this video is way too biased on the topic. i am a scientist and technician. self driving car technology does work and is significantly more advanced than the average person can know. but, like most computer scientists ... getting it working seems to be enough. because modern business models allow technology companies to release 1/2 baked working programs, while charging full price ... that is what we have accepted. 

when citing crash deaths, remember that that is based upon 250-300,000,000 drivers who perform multiple trip cycles in an average day. it will be a while before a true safety comparison is valid. while i am impressed with the ai and technology of these vehicles and fully expect them to mature ... i would never trust them in general use right now. in america, roads vary widely in quality, gps is mapped poorly in areas, ai is in its relative infancy, and technology/networks glitch with more frequency than is acceptable when life is on the line. and, don't forget that these genius cars must also enter these roadways with the very unpredictable humans you under appreciate. 

our biggest problem is that the tech giant behind this car is willing to proceed to profit margin before all of the important pre-work is even discussed. show me a multi-year plan that includes unbiased predictions of impact, high power/prospective/double-blind testing, how liability will be handled ... because mistakes will be made. i suspect that replacing the impaired drivers with these vehicles might actually be ready now, but it's ridiculous to act like this doesn't require important oversight ... provided by a competent legal system that has not been biased by lobbies.

interesting video, but unfortunately a lot of a real problems of that technology and the scenarios associated to them are not explored.
it seems in this video that autonomous cars are simply better than humans. but trust me, we have a long way before that really happens.
i'm a engineering student at a french engineering school and right now, i'm working on autonomous vehicles and technologies associated to them.
firstly, the united states and some other countries with recent and well maintained road are easy to take as examples for fully autonomous cars, in europe and other countries with older roads, complex mappings and even nonexistent "paved surface", especially on the countryside, it's not that easy.
interstates and city roads are well maintained and pretty simple to "master" for autonomous car. you can map areas that are commonly used and take advantage of the well placed and maintained elements or markers on the road in other cases.

secondly, software are able to do what we programmed them to do. it's true that almost all the time, nothing particular will happen. but playing with statistics means that at some point, your system will face something it's not programmed to handle. the problem is what will it do in that case ? will it even be able to recognize something is wrong ? what if the thing it actually tries is even worse and leads to a catastrophic event ? there is no other way for now to handle those cases than simply letting a driving operator take control to solve the issue, if it's even possible to solve the issue before facing the problem at all (to avoid an accident or crash for example).
i've seen a lot of software simply "give up" or create a worse situation because they "didn't knew" what to do or even worse : did not analyze the situation correctly.

the real future scenario is that autonomous cars and shuttles (for public transportation) will be able to drive fully autonomously in the main axis and cities where the road are well maintained and the "mapping" is already done. but having a fully autonomous car and being able to go anywhere with it without limit is not something you can count on in the near future you are talking about.

tons of daylight driving. but under rain? fog? lidar doesn't work there...  radar do tho, but they have their flaws too.

i'm a little disappointed that you barely even mentioned the limitations of waymo's phoenix operation. (best i can recall is an offhand comment that the roads are well maintained.)

phoenix was chosen for a reason - it has excellent driving weather, the roads aren't too complicated, and the traffic isn't particularly heavy. and, even with all those advantages, i believe that waymo relies on their own exhaustive (cm-scale?) mapping of the entire service area (eg. so the car knows where the road is), and i don't think this approach is particularly scalable.

yes, it's exciting that it can work at all, and it gives me a lot of hope for the future. but i think it's a long way from the eventual goal of driverless cars being safe to use on arbitrary roads.

first off i want to make it clear any technology that increases safety and decreases harm is a good thing. that being said i argue av's are not a cure all. ride share services such as uber, lyft, and taxies are great examples to compare av's too. why.. because it is a self driving vehicle (driver) that takes you to point a to point b. what results have urban planners and traffic engineers learned from this technology. driving while intoxicated has decreased, this is a good thing. whats the negative, an increase in traffic and demand for more roads. 


so whats is the goal here? are av's good or bad? av's are only one chapter in the book of safe transportation. the other chapters include engineering safer roads, (the us fails at this, it's honestly embarrassing) netherlands on the other hand does an excellent job with this by building protected bicycle lanes, forcing vehicles to slow down not with speed limit signs but by narrowing streets and adding street trees. when a vehicle accident does happen it is not only the drivers fault but also the infrastructure. ticket the driver and reengineer the road so that type of accident does not happen again, the us does not do this. also building denser communities where a traditional vehicles or av's does not does not make sense when a 15 walk or a 5 minute bike ride is faster.  

i still think av's have a place on our roads. but their overall impact is dwarfed compared basic civil engineering that prioritizes pedestrians and bicyclist and dense urban development (development that is deemed illegal in all 50 states). not to mention the hundreds of electric bicycles you can manufacture out of one electric vehicle. at the end of the day you can not out smart basic geometry.  vehicles are big, people and people on bikes are small.

29 cameras are 29 additional points of failure, lidar systems are incredibly complex systems with even more possible points of failure, and the likelihood of my two eyeballs, mark 1 and my brain, mark 1 possibly failing catastrophically at any given moment is way lower than the sudden and unexpected catastrophic failure of a camera or any other complex mechanical, optical or electronical part.
and don't even get me started on software errors. just imagine _one single_ faulty update (which we do know so well from e.g. some windows versions) which hundreds or maybe even thousands or even more autonomous cars receive at the same time - let's say for instance, monday morning right before everyone drives to work.

besides, humans don't need to be "trained" as much for extensive periods of time with huge amounts of data points to be able to cope with unexpected situations, but can react without even being trained before (not always successfull, that's true, but i still think humans outperform autonomous system by far when dealing with situations they haven't been "trained" for and have no data available).

because while autonomous system and the things they are capable of _are_ awesome, being the result of an evolutionary process which began something between 3.5 and 4.3 _billion_ years ago is nothing to be sneered at either.

so, thanks but no thanks, i'm still not convinced that autonomous cars will be feasible in the near to mean future.

8:41 i understand that machines can't make human errors but i'm skeptical that self-driving cars won't face other problems to overcome all 94% of driver error deaths. programs can fail to receive instructions, networks can fail, sensors and hardware can stop working - the machine equivalent of humans not paying attention. one failure is all it takes to make a difference between life and death in some cases (especially >100 kph, factor in extreme weather having an impact on tire traction or heat affecting circuitry in the computer, etc.). these cars are still highly dependent on all the different sensors and data processing, and i think it's dangerous to imply that we will save a world war's worth of deaths in the next century by adopting it worldwide. there is going to be a long road (no pun intended) of troubleshooting mechanical and electrical issues if these vehicles become the standard for billions of people across the world - not to mention watching companies cut corners and put out badly programmed vehicles, prioritizing profit over accessibility, and then giving ammo to reactionaries that this technology will not be long-term viable.

yes, aviaiton is highly automated and i think it is likely that we will see a further decrease in pilots required in the future however, the reason why manual landings are the standard, day or night, is simply because they far more efficient in an operational perspective (higher spacing required) and some airports are not even equipped for these approaches and they are in an guaranteed safe area by atc.

regarding the operational perspective, for sustained cat3b ils quality, the minimum seperation between aircraft has to be increased significantly. we are talking doubling, and for airports that rely on visual approaches, like sfo, quadrupling the seperation (if all aircraft were to fly behind each other). and this is not even taking into account problems with big aircraft like the a380 causing disruptions to the signal in its vicinity. 

but what i fear even more is that the autopilot takes over specific jobs that are clear and well defined, a car's autopilot can't do that and we are missing the human aspect of interaction and problem solving. in the case of planes, atc guide them a long their flightplan and around obstacles. driverless cars will have to do that themselves and i fear their behaviour in spaces,where this is required, like tight roads, will cause many issues.

i think we will see a lot of autonomous driving on streets where the quality/intensity of a conflict is not as big, regardless of the quantity, like highways that physically seperate directions. here the question of pulling out of your lane can be solved fairly easily and mathematically, plus you operate in pretty safe space in terms of homogenity of other participants and solving issues single handedly works reasonably good.

i am a software engineer, and this is something that makes me doubt very much about the future of transportation. would i ride in a fully autonomous car? sure, on a well-defined motorway with no intersections, no pedestrians, no bicycles and a full surveillance system. would i do it on a backyard road in the countryside of my native italy? not in a million years.
the things that could go wrong *instantly* in such software are just too many.

so, it seems to me, most of the issues we want to solve with driverless cars (and in general, traffic), could be solved with a combination of better public transport infrastructure, and short distance drives (autonomous or otherwise), perhaps with short term hire vehicles.

think of like a hierarchy over distance - plane/boat/train -> train -> bus/tube -> car/bicycle -> walk, at longer to shorter distances over a network of routes.  however, short distance drives are far more likely to be situations in which autonomous vehicles work poorly (countryside roads, small villages, woodland, dirt paths, driveways - frequently poorly maintained areas).  so, in an ideal world, where we have focused on economically and ecologically sustainable public transport infrastructure, the use case for autonomous vehicles drops dramatically.  where they may become useful is for local public transport - planes, trains, buses, trams - where we are already investing heavily in automation.

this fascination tech-minded people have with personal autonomous vehicles, to me, seems like a distraction from solutions which could make a real-world impact.  reducing traffic density reduces danger on a completely different level to removing human dependency.  for me, it has always seemed like a smokescreen from big business interests who want to continue selling cars, and moving towards a monopoly ownership of our roads (the natural extension of jaywalking laws in the us, for example).  it's a very cool smokescreen, and it's a very impressive technology, and it makes me say "wow, humans are so innovative, and creative".  i think that plenty of incredible individuals are working on these projects, with great moral and personal reasons for doing so.  but it lacks substance in terms of the ratio of effort to net effect that other options provide.

@veritasium - you mentioned speed bing a cause of accidents and i've been very interested in the science behind that statistic.  i think it comes from a frequentist approach to understanding crash data.  i wonder if a bayesian approach paints as dire of a picture.  while most crashes may, indeed, involve a car that was speeding, i think most cars speed.  here in sf, the de facto speed on the interstate is 80mph despite 65mph being the posted limit.  i feel like cars going slower are actually more likely to be the cause of accidents even if they might be less likely to be involved in them.  (for instance, i often see people break to move right to take an exit.  this causes people behind them to break and maybe 10 cars back a car swerves and another driver isn't paying attention leading to an accident.)  i'd be very interested to see more data on accidents.  also, i very much hope, at least in cities, we have only autonomous vehicles in the near future.  if they can all coordinate, there are huge gains in efficiency that aren't even being widely discussed.  that'd be a great video, imo, too.

if we can achieve a mix of mass movement by rail, smaller mass movement by bus and minibus (which can also be more intelligently routed), and autonomous vehicles that can do the awkward or more private journeys, and then string those things together so that a route is the most efficient it can be, multimodally - then yes, that's the dream.

very importantly, though, we have to consider cost, accessibility and (chiefly) ownership. there are many jobs to be lost here that won't be replaced. at the same time there are huge profits to be made that won't necessarily feed back into the public pocket in the way that private drivers and cabbies' taxes do. if we want a future based around this kind of tech (and i do), we need to seriously realign how the money works.

i love veritasium content and the concept of autonomous cars, however, i feel like the argumentation in some parts of this video is very biased. as someone else pointed out from a person with academic experience one would expect a more critical approach, even though a clear aim of this video was to encourage people to like the idea of autonomous transportation. to be specific: i'm not buying the part where you state that being better than an average driver would justify the widespread usage of fully autonomous cars, and it seems to be the core argument in the video.  preventing silly human errors caused by driver distraction (i.e driving straight onto stationary vehicle/object, driving off the road, speeding, drivers fatigue) which as you mentioned are the most common problems affecting road safety, can be achieved cheaper and more convenient than by introduction of fully autonomous vehicles.  
in fact most modern cars can prevent those errors using lane assists, blind spot assists, lidar-based autonomous braking systems etc. furthermore, currently, the eu requires a lot of these systems to be added to every production vehicle. these systems have been already proven to be very effective in terms of reducing overall road fatalities. 
thus to properly justify the point of general use of autonomous vehicles we should compare them to the average driver driving a modern car equipped with modern safety features.  not to mention the general cost-effectiveness and convenience. i think that fully autonomous vehicles are really the future but the future of commercial transportation not personal. they will become widespread when the cost of hiring the driver will be higher than maintaining a fully autonomous vehicle.

this make come as a surprise to many, apparently, but some of us actually like driving, and if you don't chances are you have a terrible car. a good car doesn't have to be expensive, tones of cheap cars are amazing to drive and that in turn prompts driver engagement and therefore safety.

high intake of carbs and saturated fats are just as deadly if not deadlier than cars, yet tech companies are not pushing for a future without any of those sorts of equally preventable deaths... because people's well being is not the real motivation for driverless cars, nor has it ever been, it's just an excuse: the real motivation behind driverless cars is for businesses to be able to extract more money out of people, namely by:

- getting people to focus their attention off the road and onto a screen, where they can be exposed to targeted ads;
- taking away your daily commute "me time", and make it so that you no longer have an excuse not to clock in via zoom/skype/whatever as soon as you sit in the car;

i, for one, am sick an tired of having people trying to selling me things at all times, and i don't want myself or my children to live in a world where they have to start their work day as soon as they get in the freaking car, because people should work to live, not live to work!

not to mention that not only is the technology "not there yet", it won't be anytime soon when it comes to any practical significant application and any claims on the contrary are simply marketing, because humans drive by a mix of rules and subjective "gut" decisions made in a split second, therefore any ai has to be able to take that into account in order to be able to coexist in the same road as people... and that requires animal-level ai, and we're nowhere close to that: we don't understand how the interplay between the myriad of systems that comprise a brain work together to create intelligence and consciousness, and yet people talk about the subject as if we've got it all figured out and codified in the form of a neat little algorithm!

the solution to this lack of general intelligence of our ai systems would be, of course, to ban people of the road entirely... which is much more likely... but not only would that be absolutely tyrannical, it would also be pretty stupid because that would just be a roundabout way of creating dedicated infrastructure for self-driving cars, and once you have dedicated infrastructure what you end up with is essentially a glorified, overpriced, and less energy efficient train, specially when you factor in r&d costs... which are being spent by big tech, sure, but still they could have been better spent feeding and clothing of people in need!

on a personal note, if you work in the tech field criticism of concept of self-driving cars is often equated with being an anti-vaxxer or a climate skeptic: the tech industry has managed to create such a self-serving hype around self-driving cars, that we're no longer able to have a calm, quiet, rational discussion about this subject without being branded "reactionary", foolish, and sometimes even egotistical and evil by self-driving car advocates. 

and this is no way to discuss a subject, or even do science for that matter: that's how you end up burning people at the stake for daring to think the earth revolves around the sun.

i will take a hard pass on the driverless car system for a number of reasons.
(1) this instance of workforce redundancy and phaseout would be a massive hit to the world economy. this cannot be compared to the elevator operators, typesetters, or wordprocessors. according to the bureau of transportation statistics (bts), drivers make up 9.1% of the us workforce. many of these jobs do not require a degree. where are all these "unskilled" workers going to go? even if you don't care about them, their job loss would greatly impact the us economy. (i don't have world statistics, but i would guess other developed countries would experience similar problems)
(2) the issue of liability doesn't seem to be worked out. if there is no human error, whose responsibility is it  when  two computer-driven cars crash? is it the manufacturer or the programmer? maybe there was a software update that didn't "automatically" download and install.
(3) pay-for-play-driver mode. it is bad enough that a car can cost as must as twice the original price after you add on "extras." at least that's your car. i am not interested in virtual dlc, where if i don't update the software on my car because it takes too long, or because i live in a remote area,  i now have no transportation.
(4) security: a well-informed or determined thief will always have the ability to steal a car. but at least the thief generally has to be physically present.  i am not interested in having my car stolen from some eastern european 3rd rate hacker.  also, imagine a 9/11 hijacking of 1,000 automated cars because a company got its information stolen.
(5) those cars are ugly. i enjoy driving my mitsubishi evolution x mr. i'm not interested in an auto-driven corvette. it would take all the fun out of driving the car....i.e. you would not be driving the car. then, only absolute idiots would buy exotic sports cars. 

in summary, the technology for it may be there, but just like lightbulbs that can last for hundreds of years, businesses are in the business of screwing over their customers. the current computer market should prove a warning before we turn our cars into "smartcars."

there are more reasons, but these are my top reasons to reject this notion of self-driving cars.

i definitely think we're ready for full autonomous vehicles, but there's a catch, there needs to be a massive roll out. 0.5% or even 2% of cars being autonomous isn't enough. when you have so few autonomous cars on the road, the problem is the other drivers that may get distracted by the vehicles. also humans aren't predictable. if at least 30% of cars were autonomous, they could communicate with eachother and share sensor data and suddenly you're not just using 1 car's sensor data, you're using hundreds, even thousands.

if you have 1 autonomous car tracking 10 manned cars, it can relay that data to another autonomous car that's joining up to that road via intersection. so the second car will already know where those 10 cars are before it can even see them.
if 30% of cars are autonomous, then every autonomous car will know the location of every manned car in the whole area so long as that manned car can be seen by other autonomous cars.
there could also be sensors mounted at intersections, especially more dangerous or busier intersections so the autonomous cars will have a birds eye view of the entire intersection.

also there could be basic reflectors that are better suited to autonomous cars on the sides of roads. elon musk is wrong when he said there's no future in lidar. i would not want a camera only autonomous car. sun glare affects cameras just as much as it does human eyes.

if we could get to the point where 50-60% of all cars are autonomous, i think we would be a lot better off. but i also think most autonomous cars need a manual drive function. my biggest concern was always what about snowy regions. dealing with ice and snow is just too unpredictable. and though i do think autonomous cars can handle sliding around in slow ok. at least as well as people handle it.. it's the part where you simply don't see the roads that become the issue. afterall it's your life and needs more human judgement.

i think there will be a time when your insurance is way higher if you want to drive your own car & some roads will just be off limits.  beyond that there will be a time where its not allowed or it takes special permission, like a major waver with hoops to jump through if you want to drive in big cities.  the real reasons for not having self driving cars fall under conspiracy theory and there is no way to know how that will actually go.  so it could be terrible or it could just never be a problem.  either way, it is going to happen, individually we are sorta along for the ride as the pressure of finance and safety will push us all in that direction with out a major event that makes people pay attention and make an informed decision.  i personally am looking forward to it but am also worried because eventually all these little bits of control over our own lives that we give away can eventually bite.
   its like how if you want an app on your phone that performs a specific task, you may have to let them read all your text messages and scan your pictures.  if it's a music player, there is likely one that doesn't collect your data, but for many things there may not be an app that does what you want with out the invasion.  this problem didn't have to evolve like that, but people weren't paying attention and the market developed in such a way that cleaning it out of this behavior is no longer possible.
  i remember growing up shows like eureka (among others) where there was a smart house that listened all that time and attach to the internet if it was required to get an answer.  the house computer was primarily yours and looked out for your best interest.  the a.i. was local and under your control.  but that's not what we got.  what we got is a system where you own the hardware but a company, who is looking out for their interest (not yours) actually controls the a.i.  its a subtle difference but it does matter.  the companies will do what they think they can get away with if it doesn't effect their bottom line.  the a.i. you own will protect your information unless it is necessary for something you have initiated.
  i was talking with my kids (25ish) last night and i described a situation where it was clear that some app had scanned pictures i sent to a friend.  i had sent a friend a pic of an obscure object but never named the object in text form, nor had i talked with him on the phone, nor had he looked up it or any related item.  my friend got an add for the same item the next day.  i was hesitant when telling my kids, thinking, they might think i was sounding conspiracy theorist.  i was shocked to find they all were like yeah of course they do that.  i told them "wow five years ago you might have all thought i was crazy if i said that".
  bringing it back.... cars can go the same way.  there is a quote "those who would trade their liberty for security deserve and shall have neither".  with out getting into the fact that's a misquote of a quote out of context... the idea contained in that line still rings true if you think about it.  if you, with out really understanding, give away your autonomy/liberty/what ever... to someone who doesn't have your best interest in mind... sometimes you can't get it back, or getting it back is so costly that you just continue on without that part of yourself.  giving that power to a government is questionable but necessary, with limits.  but giving it to a company is just questionable.  but given time and enough people not questioning it, but still doing it, can make it necessary for those in the future.  meaning we can give control of our future to companies.  this is why some depictions of the future in moves are of a world controlled by corporate interest.  its why some people are scared of self driving cars even if they haven't thought it all out.  they see their control leaving them and its scary.  if we as a people treated it like they aren't wrong.... they just aren't right yet, then we have a chance at avoiding the negative side of new tech.  most new techs have a down side with their up, think nuclear bomb, nuclear power.  tech is just a tool and as humans we use them.  its why good government is elected.... so we (try to) put good people in office who will reflect our views and can be replaced if they don't, who is electing the people running companies?  oh man, i just thought of an example that would happen right now if self driving cars were the standard.  in ch-eye-nah right now, if you are considered an "undesirable" by the state you can't take planes and trains, think of the no fly list but applied more liberally and to some local transit.  if they fully convert to autonomous vehicles, if you can't afford a car/parking/insurance, better hope you like biking and walking and don't need to travel to another city.

i think the biggest impact on safety and pollution would be achieved if the focus is on companies like this one making a giant network of automated taxi services, and then people could simply stop buying cars altogether. the limitations of "a taxi can't drive you too far or too late" simply don't apply to fully autonomous cars.
