i don't like how this is a sponsored video. the problem isn't that there is a sponsor, that's fine, the problem is that the scientific approach that is typically yours, where questions are asked and an answer is searched for, at least feels compromised. you sound like you're saying what the sponsor wants us to hear, but wrapping it in a veneer of sciency stuff. except many of the arguments made ring hollow or inaccurate. there are many problems with autonomous vehicles, and you only show the viewpoint of the sponsor, which is in no position to make an objective assessment, and we know it.

modern ai is arguably not learning anything, just memorizing an immense library of patterns. we do not have any feasibly ability to audit the source code of the self-driving vehicles because there essentially isn't any, just an impossible to untangle mess of various learned models taped together, with a bunch of layers. anyone who worked in software knows how things can get really ugly really fast in the real world, even when humans know what the software is meant to do and how it's designed, and from what little has transpired out of companies like tesla, we know their software efforts do not exist on some ethereal plane of existence where the typical problems don't apply.

those vehicles are trained in often unrealistic scenarios: only on simple, wide, straight american (st)roads, or only in clear weather conditions, or with training data with "exceptional" events culled away for easier training. you make the analogy to elevators and airplanes, but really that's silly, because those are effectively on rails, much like trains. cars are _not_ trains and roads at _not_ rails. the possibility space is much smaller, and there is no complex reading of human behavior required to insert in elevator or air corridor traffic. on a road, you come into much closer contact, at much faster speeds, with other agents, who are very hard to predict and to read, even for humans sometimes. simply playing it safe and avoiding the hard situations will not work in the real world, and neither will deferring to a driver who was told they could relax. asking for an overnight transition is even less.

context is impossible for self-driving cars to understand: a suicidal person walking towards the road with bad intentions, kids playing on the side, people having a bbq, or whatever context where people are in line of sight for the car, are impossible to distinguish for an ai, it will just see people near the road. because of that, the car will be tuned to react overly confident, or underconfident, or likely both. how does a driverless car react to other dangerous drivers attempting road-rage manoeuver ? yes it won't get "angry", but it can still very likely get outside of comfortable operation conditions and be put in a situation it wasn't trained on. what about learner drivers ? intoxicated drivers ? someone having a stroke ? a mechanical failure ?

a human does need training to react to every possible scenario, because it has a _brain_ and understands what it is doing. what humans are trash at is boring driving conditions and boring everyday commutes where people are effectively driving in autopilot mode themselves, not fully aware of the situation. this is where driving aids come into their own, and can augment the driver awareness. this is desirable. what i'm less sure about is leaving that sweet spot for systems that involve the human so little it completely loses any involvement, because then the human insight into context is lost to the vehicle.

the next part is this tech is exploitable. adversarial attacks on those networks are not a new thing, and that's before you get in the actual infosec security issues of having fully drive-by-wire cars with network connectivity to the drivetrain. you'd be hard pressed to find _any_ security researcher who's honestly _not_ nervous about safety-critical closed-source systems connected to the internet, let alone who would trust one with his own life.

lastly i don't like what this means in a world were all cars are autonomous. this tech isn't free, it is owned by some of the biggest conglomerates who already have a dangerous level of control over our lives. in a future where only autonomous cars are allowed, and where we no longer own our cars, we are now tributary of the whims of that corporation for getting around. losing your google account is bad enough today, but tomorrow it could mean you can get stranded. or it could mean a cartel could own the pricing for transportation and artificially raise it for profit maximization. we've seen how that does wonders already in plenty of areas in tech. forfeiting the privilege of driving to machines means losing it to a couple dozen companies, who will exert total control on who is allowed on the roads, which were supposed to be public infrastructure.

is human freedom worth loss of life ? now you have some real questions to discuss, and historically the answer has been a big fat "it's complicated".

while i don't agree or disagree with you it's important to remember how many obstacles exist for innovative ideas such as autonomous vehicles.

when they speak about reducing congestion i imagine they are talking about how an extremely large amount of congestion is caused by human drivers.
imagine a long line of human drivers taking off from a stop, they "caterpillar" along and do not accelerate at the same rate.
compared to a long line of autonomous vehicles which can all accelerate at the same rate without risk of collision.

then you can begin to think about how this can be a solo ride or a ride share, which could further reduce congestion if people are willing to share a ride that would mean anywhere from 1 to 5 (regular sedan) less vehicles on the road.

as for the infrastructure... roads exist. the cost of developing software and building these vehicles would pale in comparison to any conceivable large scale mass transit rail system.
this makes this technology accessible to people, not just corporations or governments who are happy with the status quo because it makes them wealthy.

as for parking... i imagine that you can book your vehicle for a certain time of day or call one up within minutes which will then take you wherever you're going and if you have these vehicles with significantly more uptime than a personal vehicle (they mentioned 95% downtime in the video for personally owned vehicles on average) then there doesn't need to be as many vehicles on the road to service the same population of people.
you would obviously have peak transit times and if those vehicles aren't in use they need to be on standby somewhere...
but the ideal situation they talk about i think refers to the roads and vehicles being predominantly autonomous which could mean a drastic reduction in the requirements for parking spaces.

if this service was available to me where i live i would use it. i think the implications and benefits far outweigh the negatives, even if it is just a bandaid until something much more innovative replaces it in the future, that doesn't mean that it was a waste and served no purpose.

i will preface this by saying that fully autonomous cars are absolutely the future but level 5 autonomy is still a long way off.

the issue that i have with this video is that it draws (currently) invalid parallels to aircraft autonomy. automated aircraft landings are a much simpler task than navigating icy/snowy roads (traffic is controlled by the tower; position, elevation, and orientation of the runway is known and unchanging). there is a reason why waymo is doing it's pilot program in phoenix. determining how to navigate a vehicle in adverse weather conditions is proving to be a very difficult problem to solve. radar, lidar, and computer vision all have different edge cases which are difficult to account for.

your arguments to prove that autonomous agents are better are weak. both elevators and airplanes operate under very strict set of parameters. their entire environment is built under the assumption that they will operate autonomously. elevators have multiple emergency hardware. they are also built with much higher safety margin. we don't have elevators that can change hoistways. the planes without the set of required navigation and safety hardware with at least two redundancies are not allowed to go higher than a specific height. the routes are constantly watched by atc personnel for any deviations. the serious violators will have their license revoked. the smallest deviations from intended operations are also logged by the pilots to be checked. the majority of the safety of elevators and airplanes are not the result of autonomous systems but the policies that allow the autonomous systems to operate in well defined environments.

so to counter the asiana airlines incident, there is also turkish airlines flight 1951 where an autonomous computer decision based on broken radio altimeter crashed the airplane. 

the equivalent for roads would be rebuilding roads entirely, equipping cars with more proactive hardware  and implementing very strict license requirements. effectively making driving a hard to obtain privilege. this is how it's done in western europe. obtaining a license is really hard and expensive. there are strict yearly checks for cars on the street. the violations are subject to an escalating system and your license will be taken away permanently if you cause too many violations. this is why the usa has the vehicle related fatality rate ~11 / 100k while germany has ~3 / 100k population.

the cheapest and safest solution to the human transportation on land is having good public transportation which can be automated pretty easily and will push human fatalities quite a bit down.

while i do think autonomous cars have a future especially after implementing policies to make roads safer. the problem is social, not technical. it requires social solutions.

sorry, but derek is way too optimistic here.

lidar only works in good weather conditions (e.g. heavy fog or water spray from cars in front is deadly), same for cameras. and those ranges of 300m for lidar and 500m for camera sound absolutely unbelievable! like, pick any sign on a local road, walk 500m away, take a picture and then try to read the sign in the image. you won't. typical ranges one talks about when using cameras in autonomous driving are like 100-150m max.

also, you see at least 4 lidar-sensors mounted on the car in the video. has anyone thought about the cost? the 360¬∞ one on top is at least 30,000$, the others probably like half of that each. on top of that you have the 28(!) cameras (some of them with expensive lenses, if they are supposed to come even close to what is claimed) and several radar sensors. the latter typically cost about 1,500$ each. in sum this means that just the sensor equipment costs more than most normal cars! how is this supposed to go into a mass-produced consumer product?

last point i want to make: energy consumption. with electric cars we are already talking about their comparably low driving range. all of these sensors and especially the gpus/tpus and processors needed to make use of the data need a lot, and i really mean *a lot*,  of power. this doesn't go well together at all.
(before anyone mentions tesla: they have never used close to this many sensors or had such a high level of automation. and there is a reason why they recently announced that they will exclusively rely on cameras in the future.)

overall, i must say that this video feels like a big (false) advertisement to me, as harsh as that may sound. not for waymo specifically, but autonomous cars in general. maybe derek is just a tad too excited about them?

so, i know this is a sponsored video to increase use confidence in autonomous driving, but i would have liked more critical views on the numbers and comparisons shown. 

for example, 1 million miles driven by a computer is not comparable to 1 million miles driven by a human. both learn differently, and thus the "experience" gained is not comparable. derek never really said they are directly comparable, but the implication was strong, and i don't really agree with that.

the plane example is popular, but also a misrepresentation. think about this: why did we have automatic flight systems for a few decades before there was fully autonomous driving?
flying a plane is hard for humans for different reasons than it is for computers. for average untrained humans, there are too many sensors and actors (known inputs) to pay attention to. also, humans are not very good at replicating a certain action perfectly every time. computers can handle a great number of known inputs quite well. what makes flying easier for computers than driving on public roads are the unknown inputs: situation and circumstance. the airspace is mostly empty. there are fewer situations with external factors, where a computer would have a hard time to give a proper reaction. and landing in foggy weather is not harder for a computer to do, because the chosen inputs for the control system can deal with that. which is good, but you can't use that to argue, that computers by definition handle situations better than humans. 
cars are the other way around: much fewer known inputs (good for humans), but a large number of unknown inputs due to dense traffic. humans can deal with that much better than computers. 
please don't use automatic flight systems to argue computers can handle autonomous driving better than humans. 

the video shows a lot of empty roads with low density traffic. if that is the situation, then human error is also less likely to cause an accident. and distraction and intoxication are good reasons for public transport for example. 
what i would have liked to see is not a total number of human error accidents vs computer error accidents, but rather to distinguish the traffic situation. 

now, do i believe autonomous driving can work? yes of course, it is demonstrated in the video. for the kind of traffic shown in very confident autonomous driving will be better than average human drivers, at some point even better than very good drivers.
but what i don't see is s mostly autonomous driving traffic all around the world. in my opinion, this will remain more of a novelty in rich, developed areas with well-managed traffic. 
what i would rather see is assisted driving. since there are actual problems human drivers have (such as a very limited viewing area), certain assistants will make human-controlled driving much more safe. 
autonomous driving is not a good solution for large-scale mobility of a society. we essentially can't just replace all of our cars with autonomous vehicles, because that is not sustainable. we are very much used to individual mobility, where essentially every adult has their own car and can drive when and where they want. climate change and pollution show, that this can not sustain. 
we need a new mobility, and public transport needs to be much more included again. autonomous taxis might be a small part in it, limited to well-developed areas. 
in the end, autonomous driving is a bit like the last straw for the car industry to promote a long-term future for their product. but at this point we should be aware, that individual mobility how we are doing it now is not sustainable, if we think 50 years ahead, or even less. 

conclusion: the video was fun, and as an engineer i'm excited about the cool technological solutions shown. and i would ride an autonomous car if i get the chance. but i'm my option, some of the key arguments in this video are misleading, and that is a bit disappointing. even for a sponsored video.

some points of critique:
- the number of hours of data a system is trained on is not a good measure of how safe the system is. with ai it just tells how ingrained patterns have become and how resistant to changes it now is. overtraining an ai system is a thing as well, where it will find patterns where there are none and behave erratically. it gives mild confidence that it has seen some edge cases, but the statistic alone gives no confidence that it can handle situations a human *could* handle if they encounter it. an actual list of situations it should pass, and looking through that data if it actually encountered it would be much more useful.
- the statistics about the number of incidents do say something about safety, but only in the environment it has driven. which, right now, seems to be two places: suburbs outside of phoenix, arizona, and in san francisco and mountain view, california.
- the point at the beginning of the video that a lot of people think self-driving cars are >10 years away, and that this is not the case because you are riding in one is poorly substantiated. the system is trained on san francisco, and probably works fine in san francisco, but that doesn't mean it will translate well to another city in the us, the countryside or another country entirely. this has nothing to do with "badly maintained roads", and more with different scenarios the system has never encountered before. the ability to identify parked cars on the road. the ability to identify when it *should* go with two wheels off-road (which you say it doesn't), because the road is too small for two vehicles to pass. the ability to identify when it cannot go with two wheels off-road and should stop at a part of the road that is a bit wider, designed to let two vehicles pass on a road that is usually too narrow for that. the ability to identify bike roads, where cars are allowed but cyclists can use the entire width of the road. situations where road rules tell the car that it has right of way, but where human drivers commonly stop to let traffic pass for one reason or another.
- when looking at safety, replacing a random normal car with an autonomous car is not as simple as looking at "is this car safer than the average driver". you also have to look at scalability of the system, and what happens if you have, for example, a 100 of these cars on the same road. right now, i would assume that these cars actively blind each other with their lidar. i would assume they can handle some data corruption due to that, but it makes the cars less reliable.
- the animation of an intersection where cars just communicate with each other instead of waiting for traffic lights is still a long way away. such an intersection requires absolute trust between vehicles, because every vehicle on that intersection must know and trust every other vehicle on that intersection to have a plan, and execute that plan exactly as advertised. that would require 100% autonomous cars, and the only way you could trust a car 100% is if they run your software and you know its internal reasoning, or if there is some protocol in place that can handle cases like cars just not communicating. this car is not capable of doing that, and is unlikely to be able to do that in the near future.
- moral dilemmas do not cease to be moral dilemmas if your average driver is incapable of making the decision in the first place. waymo's vehicles predict several future scenarios. it will try it's best to get to a destination, and try it's best to avoid collisions while doing so. but it will make decisions based on the data it receives, and those decisions are made by those who tweak the vehicle time after time. and most (moral) dilemmas are not as uncommon as the ones you showcased. for example: should the car break if a ball-like object bounces on the street, and the car is not predicted to hit it? if a trash can falls over on the street, and it predicts it cannot break to avoid hitting it, should it swerve around it? if a car hits a barrier and bounces into traffic in front of an autonomous car, should it break or swerve? what about if there is a heavy truck behind the car? what about if swerving has the potential for no other collisions to occur? what if that chance is 1%? these decisions have already been made by the people working on waymo, either by tackling such edge cases or letting the ai network decide on it's own. you have a point that waiting for those moral dilemmas to all be solved before using autonomous vehicles is not going anywhere (we have infinite many of them), but i think you make light of these moral dilemmas. these are moral dilemmas that need to be solved, because it shouldn't be up to the programmers of the vehicle to make that call, or to come up with edge cases to test for.

that said, you make some good points. people are notoriously bad at driving and drive-assist or fully autonomous vehicles can help with that. a large quantity of autonomous vehicles can reduce congestion on highways, because they just automatically drive the same speed as each other and do not swerve left and right all the time. autonomous vehicles are great for people that cannot or do not want to drive a car, and have to get around in places where there is no or inadequate public transport. i just wished you would have looked in a more critical way at this.

as you say, lidar only works in good weather conditions (e.g. heavy fog or water spray from cars in front is deadly), same for cameras. and those ranges of 300m for lidar and 500m for camera sound absolutely unbelievable! like, pick any sign on a local road, walk 500m away, take a picture and then try to read the sign in the image. you won't. typical ranges one talks about when using cameras in autonomous driving are like 100-150m max.

also, you see at least 4 lidar-sensors mounted on the car in the video. has anyone thought about the cost? the 360¬∞ one on top is at least 30,000$, the others probably like half of that each. on top of that you have the 28(!) cameras (some of them with expensive lenses, if they are supposed to come even close to what is claimed) and several radar sensors. the latter typically cost about 1,500$ each. in sum this means that just the sensor equipment costs more than most normal cars! how is this supposed to go into a mass-produced consumer product?

last point i want to make: energy consumption. with electric cars we are already talking about their comparably low driving range. all of these sensors and especially the gpus/tpus and processors needed to make use of the data need a lot, and i really mean *a lot*,  of power. this doesn't go well together at all.

i really like the idea of driverless cars, but for a whole bunch of reasons i don't see them becoming widespread for, as you mentioned, another 10 years. first off - and most importantly - so much of the data on this stuff seems to be self-reported from for-profit companies, and i just can't shake the feeling that they have motive and opportunity to hide some of their less favorable statistics in the interests of creating shareholder value. 

secondly, while i strongly believe that driverless cars are better than average humans at certain tasks, i also strongly believe that they're *worse* than humans at other tasks. i very, very strongly doubt that the venn diagram of driverless vs driver skills completely contains all driver skills perfectly. we've had over a century of time to revise and tweak the human driving experience to account for a lot of human shortfalls, but porting those tweaks over to an entirely new driver system is going to present us with a lot of unpredictable situations. 

also, i just don't trust computer vision yet. it's made some huge strides over the past decade, but it's noisy output and inability to reason are just one of those things that can fail catastrophically when you least expect it. like, a human would know if they saw a car teleporting all over the road they should probably either steer well clear of the entire situation or pull over and get some rest. but for a lot of computer vision that's just a fact of life, smoothed out in software to facilitate a more comfortable passenger experience.

and finally, the big one: this is going to take a long, long, long long time to legislate. even if they are perfectly reliable, even if they are perfectly tested, we have over a century of (critical!) rules and regulations that would need to be amended, overturned and revised. in america you'll likely see them sooner, since the rights of big business seem to always be preferred to public safety, but in europe and a lot of the rest of the world, it's going to be a substantially more lengthy process to ensure the safety of the public is ensured. not that americans would likely get completely off the hook; you also have a huge number of people who are violently afraid of change, and i fully expect to hear about roving gangs of anti-autonomy brigades deliberately running autonomous vehicles off the road in the name of freedom.

as i said, i fully believe that this will be coming in future, although i suspect a lot of it will only happen after some countries do a significant autonomy-friendly infrastructure pass with wireless communication beacons and computer-vision-friendly signage and the like.

big fan of veritasium. here's my criticism of this video though:
1. in an elevator, there are zero external factors to control for. in an airplane, it's just the environment which the computer needs to compute for, that too on an almost completely predictable, standardised runway with the best, most expensive safety measures. these do not even compare to driving on the road - especially when there are such crazy drivers on it. i live in india, and the traffic in a large city such as bangalore is often much, much more sane than traffic in a small city such as mysore, where people will drive in completely crazy ways, with no regard for any rules. they'll drive full speed on the wrong side, or come into the main road at 90¬∞ at full speed in a two wheeler with three helmetless riders on it. the lights will switch from green to red with no warning, etc. can computers really intuit how crazy humans will behave? humans often can.
2. following up on the last statement, 20 million miles as a rock in a driverless car is worth nothing, because rocks cannot think. of course, the algorithms these cars use are sophisticated, but can we really compare the miles of experience of a computer vs the miles of experience of a human? humans learn a lot of things very fast and intuitively, especially how other humans will behave. we've had billions of years of evolution training us for  this. computers with all their decades of training cannot even speak like a normal human being, something a four year old easily can. computers still kinda suck at object recognition, but a kitten a few months old has no problem.
3. and my weakest point here: sure, these cars might reduce the human error accidents that we know about, but will they introduce new errors that we don't know about? i think that's the fear everyone who's anxious about these vehicles has. both the 8% of "terrified" people, and the ~40% of "10+ years away" people.

that said, here's what i think stands in favour of the computers:

a. they can share knowledge, so every extra computer adds more knowledge quickly.

b. they can simulate different situations (but so can we; we also imagine different scenarios. especially when we have an almost-accident, we imagine how bad it would have been if the accident actually occurred.)

c. suppose a car from a thousand years in the future arrives here today. and in this future, autonomous car accidents are unheard of. my anxiety with the car would still exist - it would have to drive for a while before i feel safe. i think that the people getting worried about the edge cases of whom to kill are really manifesting a slightly different and much more understandable anxiety. our anxieties are dependent on our experience in the car. our judgement of how well the car is driving is based on what kind of mistakes a bad human driver will make, not the kind of mistakes a bad ai might make - we just don't have the right tools to judge an ai. an ai might feel like a safe human driver for 10 hours and then just run right over a wayward pedestrian - that psychopathic possibility is something we cannot judge as humans. hence the fear. the only cure is experience and statistics - total miles driven without incident, and it's nice to see that at least in the (i'm assuming) well-behaved us, these particular cars are doing well.

i can't wait to have them in australia.  i fully support the viewpoint that these will reduce accidents, contrary to the belief some people have that accidents will increase due to autonomous vehicles.  i'm very glad derek(?) pointed out that human error is the primary cause of motor vehicle accidents.  many people drive recklessly and take risks.  one thing i didn't hear mentioned is human emotions; they can tend to cloud judgment in critical situations.  my mother had been a very careful driver, but was highly susceptible to panic when anything unexpected happened - that doesn't happen with machines.  in my own case i've never had a drivers licence because my depth perception is too poor.  even though i can see clearly, i can't judge distances well or adequately gauge the speed and direction of nearby vehicles and pedestrians.  it has never been safe for me to drive.

derek(?) used a comparison of automatic elevators as a reference to the emerging technology of fully autonomous vehicles.  however this reminds me of something even older still.  in the very earliest days of railways there were no trackside signals; only employees/police giving hand signals.  the 25/08/1861 clayton tunnel rail crash occurred in one of the earliest rail blocks to have signals, and despite the root cause being human error some people living at the time drew the conclusion that railway signals would actually increase accidents instead of reducing them.  today we know that not to be the case.  hopefully in a generation we'll have more acceptance of fully autonomous vehicles.

the only concern i have about this emerging technology is what it will do to the job market and economy.  what will happen to people whose livelihood relies on driving?  will all transport vehicles, including container trucks be driverless in the future?

you're right about this being the future, but the technology is just not here yet.  

while yes, it would instantly save lives, and i'm all for a future where i don't own a car, they simply can't handle all situations, and just because more people will live, doesn't mean a specific individual will be safer.

the sensors and programming just haven't had enough real world testing.  from glitches to bugs in code to sensor failure to computerized attack, there are too many variables, and not yet enough data to get it right.  these vehicles still struggle to drive in the snow and rain.

it will be a long hard road to perfecting this.  much like your example of the pilot that took over and crashed the plane.  why haven't we gotten rid of pilots yet then?  ultimately the problem is control.  we feel like an elevator is perfect and safe, but it took decades after the technology was perfected.  we are looking at a similar timeline.  who do you prosecute when a driverless car runs someone over?  where is the blame, the lawsuits?  people like accountability, and yes, since most people believe they are above-average drivers, they will expect they are safer driving themselves.  after all, most people never experience a serious accident, and often prevent accidents with their driving ... of course they think highly of their abilities.  

an elevator and a plane are much simpler, and most of that boils down to obstacles, neither has to avoid hitting people in operation.  sensors will get better, coding will become more robust, redundancy is the name of the game, and the only way to ensure we feel safe in and around them.

it isn't just about lives.  i put forth you could save more lives by letting a computer feed you instead of choosing your own meals.  people are just not wired to play life that safe or passively.

we will get there, i feel there are many circumstances i would already use a self-driving car now.  but we have a long way to make it work perfectly enough.  ultimately it may just take a huge quick shift.  if every car on the road is self-driving and communicating with each other, no crashes with other vehicles would happen - ever.

you talk about how many cumulative miles have been driven and how much "experience" they've had, but these comparison are always contrived because it's not an apples to apples comparison. the major benefit of having a human brain learn to drive is that we can explain why we do and don't make certain decisions for any given event. in the ai/ml world, all we can do is provide thousands or millions of examples and hope that the computers infer the right outcomes from any given set of inputs.

please stop saying there was a small chance of these unrealistic trolley accidents happening!
these are 100% impossible!

scenario 1: you are approaching the 2 persons/vehicles/whatever with good visibility: hit the goddamn breaks! => no one gets hurt
scenario 2: you are approaching the 2 persons/vehicles/whatever with bad visibility: drive slowly! if you can not break in time, you were driving too fast for the conditions in the first place! => no one gets hurt
scenario 3: the objects appear out of thin air within your breaking distance: nothing to argue here because an autonomous car can break much more quickly than a human and a human would hit both of them anyways! => autonomous car does not prevent the accident (which is impossible) but minimizes injuries due to faster response times and therefore slower impacts.

tldr: cars have breaks! use them!

sorry, but this is literally from the waymo website:

"weather conditions like rain, sleet and snow reduce the effectiveness of on-board sensors. in fact, some weather conditions may completely blind a sensor, making it useless. if falling snow gathers on the front of a lidar unit, then it can no longer return 3d data for the vehicle‚Äôs perception engine."

this is why the service currently only operates is phoenix where it's almost always sunny. it's skewed data, based solely on it being sunny all day every day. there's also the possibility to fine tune map data for navigation on a smaller scale compared to real world data. anyone who has ever used a gps in their life has had times where it redirects them the wrong way, tells them to get into the wrong lane, or worse still drives the wrong way down a one way street.

- 1) autonomous cars can be hacked and that's not something that should be accepted, and it's not a problem that can be avoided (until we have quantum computers and internet). we have ransomware today, maybe in the future if we allow these cars we can imagine that a ransomware that will just lock you in your car until you pay for example, or just render your car unable to start or whatever malicious thing.

my question with regard to the adoption of autonomous vehicles is what will become of those times when you want to simply go out in your sportscar and enjoy going for a drive?

when horses stopped being used as a method of transportation there was a change towards horses being used as part of a recreational pursuit for those in society who still see the appeal of horses.  not that i personally see the appeal of riding a horse, i do understand why others would see this appeal and i am therefore ok with society making provisions so that those who want to ride horses can do so.  will society in the future still be supportive of the people who still want to enjoy talking their vehicle out for a drive?  would it be practical to preserve certain scenic roads for the pursuit of going for a non-autonomous drive?  

it seems to me that having an interest in horse riding is something that is the reserve of the wealthier more privileged people in society as it is quite an expensive hobby/sport/interest.  will access to being able to enjoy driving non-autonomous vehicle also become something that will become the reserve of the wealthy?

i love this technology, but there's one problem i struggle with. it feels like another angle on the infrastructure problem in that cities become congested, because everyone is almost expected to have their own car and drive it everywhere, so cities widen roads, add streets and relent to this massive influx of cars, but they just fill up again, congesting again. you can't have a city where everyone lugs their 2 ton vehicle with them, it's incredibly ineffici√´nt. so i actually just wish this will somehow bleed over in a new form of public transport. like trams that don't need tracks, basically. because a future where everyone has their own massive vehicle, just isn't sustainable, even if it drives itself.

in an autonomous driving future, most families will own 1 car instead of 2. many families will not own a car at all. we'll use autonomous taxis instead. a autonomous taxi can probably serve the needs of 5 families - that's better for the environment and cheaper than everyone buying their own car. the only problem is peak rush hour, but with more people working from home, that will be less of an issue in future too. society will gradually adapt, there may be more workers who start their day at 9:30 or 10am, simply to extend the rush hour peak and reduce the total number of autonomous cars required to serve everyone - which makes the fares cheaper.

also public transport will be improved, too. instead of buses that seat 30-40 people with 1 driver on a few routes, we may have autonomous shuttles that seat 6-12 without drivers on many more routes. they may even be services were people can propose tailored public transport routes, other people can vote for them, and the most popular ones get put into service (like car pooling but more flexible). one big limitation of public transport is the frequency, which is strictly limited by the drivers. without having drivers, you could have buses or shuttles arriving every 3-4 minutes.

@@yaomtc how would it result in more vehicles on the road? i mean they would be replacing human drivers on the road, so wouldn't it be a net neutral result? and with cars communicating with one another congestion would be significantly reduced, since it's mostly a result of poor driving that causes a butterfly effect. and it would be safer for pedestrians, since most pedestrian injuries are a result of human drivers, and would remain so. it feels like most of the points you made are wrong when painting the picture of an autonomous future.

i'm one of those that are concerned with driverless cars, and my problem isn't doubt in the capabilities, even though there will be system errors that will waste lives, it will, over all, be much safer to get from a to b.

but it is the abstraction that scares me, the last 200 years, humans have become increasingly better at abstracting away details we don't want to deal with, but what isn't spoken about, is how vulnerable it makes us.
in all simplicity we are trading control and knowledge for convenience, and that makes us vulnerable, especially since "it" was born.

i believe the "it-fication" going on around the world currently, is a glimpse into a scary future.

there are only so many car vendors, what if a software bug strikes many vehicles at once, causing thousands to die within hours of the update being deployed?

even worse: there will always be evil out there;

agreed. literally any condition that is rare and not covered by the training data is going to either brick these cars (they pull over and strand the driver because they can't proceed safely) or get people killed. unusual road signs, unusual construction conditions, unusual behavior by other human drivers, local driving cultures (e.g. in some cities you must turn left on yellow or you will never be able to turn, in other cities this practice is really dangerous because the timing of the yellow lights is different...human drivers learn this by watching other driver behaviors), determining intent of pedestrians and cyclists, visual perception in exceptionally difficult visibility situations, etc. as advanced as ai is, it's very limited by what it has been able to gleen from the training data. the world is constantly changing and there will always be new conditions never contemplated by the training data. right now the cars have human drivers to learn from. if there's ever a future where most drivers are machines then suddenly the ais will have a harder time adapting to novelty without killing people or bricking in the process.

driverless cars are a cool idea, but ultimately they're a distraction from what should be the future of transit: fuckin trains.  subways, light rail.  freight trains for shipping.  cars are a dead end technology that's literally killing the planet.  it's so inefficient to move around two tons of metal just to transport one to four humans.  self-driving cars can paper over the cracks in places where trains aren't practical for whatever specific reason, but the solution to nearly every problem with cars isn't to make a different kind of car - it's to make a goddamn train.

people seem to have the misconception that autonomous vehicles were made for convenience instead of safety. self-driving cars were not made so that we can just sit back and relax; they were made to reduce accidents and save lives. people in vehicles will always need to pay attention, just like how pilots still need to be in the cockpit. technology is never a 100% guarantee. the future of vehicles will still be us looking at the road; only difference is that we won't have our hands on the wheel.

driverless cars are pretty cool, and if they do increase safety that's not a bad thing, but there are a couple of pet peeves i have with some of the things presented in this video. this is a pretty long comment, so if you don't want to read all of it, the most important thing in my opinion is that *_public transport was completely ignored in this video._* this is explained in more detail in the last paragraph:

‚Äì the arguments about autonomous elevators and planes imply that this is a valid direct comparison. however, they aren't really comparable to driverless cars. ignore that the plane finds the runway using infrastructure at the airport, the localizer system, and it still should become clear that, even though there are other planes in the sky, what the autopilot of planes and elevators do is essentially operating without traffic. for a driverless car to meet this requirement, all it has to do is be able to follow roads and turn into driveways or parking lots _(which it may actually not even be able to do in all cases because it may rely on road markings, but depending on where it's used, this is irrelevant)._ it should be clear that this is not the concern most people have about self-driving cars.

‚Äì the argument about driver experience comes with a similar flaw: yes, the system has much more data than any human could ever collect themselves on the road, but humans learn magnitudes faster than machines. machines need exponentially more data to match what a human can achieve with a given amount of experience. of course, the difference in data here is huge, so there is likely still a valid argument in there, but it's presented to be much more extreme than it actually is.

‚Äì that an autonomous car drives confidently and passes your mental checks doesn't mean it would actually do well in an extreme situation. while with a human, you are likely to see somewhat easily how good of a driver they are overall, it's impossible to predict for sure if at some point a gap in the autonomous driving system may become apparent. a situation that never came up in the training data and that the car maybe chooses to handle badly. this doesn't discredit the safety of driverless cars overall, because these situations are unlikely _(this kind of plays into your argument about ethics discussions),_ but it should be noted that, especially with autonomous "black box" systems, there can be a big difference between feeling safe and being safe. human drivers can cause this effect, too _(especially in their own judgement of themselves, but as you are a passenger in the autonomous vehicle, we should also evaluate humans as passengers),_ but it's far less likely that an otherwise very good driver will have an incredibly specific weakness. again, this doesn't make autonomous cars unsafe, but the fact that you can sit in the back and be comfortable doesn't validate that.

‚Äì the advantages of autonomous driving presented at 16:41 are all achievable at higher safety than any car-based system by expanding public transport. this would also be more ecological. of course, there is the advantage to self-driving cars that they are more convenient as they take you from the start to the destination directly, without any walking or switching vehicles. but it is worth discussing whether this alone is enough to make driverless cars the preferable option. one might even argue that if we are going to give up some safety, compared to public transport, for the sake of convenience, we might as well give up even more of it for the convenience of owning our own cars...
but disregarding that, discussing the convenience, safety, comfort, capacity and environmental impacts of public transport and autonomous cars in comparison to one another makes a lot of sense and i personally feel should be a main point in this video. *it should certainly not be left out altogether.*

‚Äã@dave the lidar these vehicles (and most autonomous vehicles) rely on is impacted by those things just as much as human vision.

also, the set-up of a human driver a couple feet behind a large windshield is much less easily obstructed than the small apertures these vehicles sensors rely on.

third, humans are still better at extrapolating from incomplete information  than the demonstrated capacity of the ai systems that have been developed for these vehicles.

in truth, i was thinking less about visual obstruction than about dealing with uncleared roads after a large snowfall, when many road cues are obstructed... but visual obstruction is a problem too. there's a reason these things are being tested in places like phoenix and socal.

under decent conditions, i do think self-driving cars are viable. under bad conditions, such as poorly maintained roads without lane markings, construction sites with unusual lane shifts, or heavy snow that blocks the sensors, i still wouldn't trust it. it's not like an elevator where there's only one way to go, or an airplane where there's extremely well-defined markings and an abundance of sensors the plane can use. cars need more data than is readily available and sensors need to be more robust in wintry conditions.

and then there's the question of making it affordable, because i think these need to be below the average car price of about us $40,000 before they're going to make a meaningful impact on the market. otherwise, it's going to struggle to get past the early adoption phase.

given all that, i think we're at least a decade out from something that's ready to be marketed to consumers and another decade before it's affordable to the masses. i wouldn't be surprised to see human-driven cars banned by 2075, though.

i'm somewhat disappointed by the video and found it to be a very simplistic take, as well as very american-centric. a lot of the video was dedicated toward human attitudes and behaviour regarding self driving cars, while very little was focussed on technology readiness. eg. how will the cars handle it if every car is fitted with lidar? surrounded by 100 cars each with multiple lidars will it still function or be rendered useless, perhaps something in between with phantom detections?

there was so much nuance that was either brushed over or ignored, attributing poor performance to such throwaway comments as, "in some parts of the world the roads aren't well enough maintained." meanwhile you're driving round in perfect conditions on very wide american style roads, many of which are dual carriageways. try that waymo car on a narrow country road in the uk and see how it does, my bet is that it would cross the lane divider frequently just as tesla's do too. self driving cars that are trained on very wide american roads are actually dangerous and not fit for purpose on narrower uk and european roads. they also seem to be averse at making strong control inputs, which means that tight turns and corners are an issue for them, but again not a problem on wide roads with sweeping turns, and all intersections meet at 90 degrees.

i'm not a luddite, and i of course accept that in certain conditions and on certain types of road (essentially dual carriageways and motorways), they are undoubtedly better drivers and never suffer lapses in concentration. however i have not seen anything to suggest that any self driving tech has even come close to driving safely on smaller and more congested roads.

with regards to your poll at 1:20 these options are not mutually exclusive, i am both excited to see a future where they exist and function well, but at the same time i still think it will be >10 years before full unmonitored self-driving is ready.
funny thing is if this actually takes off and in the future certain areas of a country will be autonomous cars only, the engineers of the future will wonder why we made the cars so complicated.

the worst will be the transition period. when there is a lot of autonomus cars as well as the manually operated ones. because the hardest part for the machines is and always will be: human behavior. then, at some point, in not so distant future, there will be a shift, it will be caused not by the fashion, marketing, morals nor law, but by the simple factor of prices of liability insurance. price of liability insurance is derived from statistics - and statistically, automated cars will be causing so little incidents that it will quickly become extremely expensive to legally drive manually and really, really cheap, to just go driverless. in few short decades, licensed human drivers are going to be about as numerous as astronauts today. at least in the richer parts of the world.  the automated cars can communicate with each other to the level that we might start to need way less of them than we currently need of the normal cars, plus they will be able to create constant, fluent traffic, with stops only necessary for getting passengers on and off plus battery changes. this will also eliminate the need for actually owning a car. automobility will become an universally available service instead. and at this point, driving a car manually in traffic might become illegal or even humanly impossible. some might like it less than others, but this is the only possible way forward.

i'm generally in favor of self-driving cars, but i don't trust companies that are famous for corner-cutting with the design and manufacture of them. and also, the world has a lot of variety when it comes to roads. one thing the human brain will be vastly superior to computers at -- at least, for the foreseeable future -- is making a decision we weren't at all trained, or "programmed" to make. just recently there was a tweet going around about a tesla thinking the moon was a yellow light. you don't have to teach a human driver that the moon doesn't affect traffic, but that is something you need to make an explicit exception for with a computer. now, multiply that by a billion, and you have all the little decisions that human drivers make without even thinking about it. humans are really good at discarding irrelevant information, and training computers to do that takes a lot of effort. i'm very much looking forward to seeing the technology develop, but anxious about it being developed by those who are looking to make a quick buck.

i know you said this was sponsored, but it really felt like an advertisement.  you didn't look at the negatives or explain why pilots (not just 1, but 2 and sometimes 3) are still there if the planes can be run autonomously.  living in canada, i can tell you snow, mud, slush are big negatives.  i know the states get snow down low (big texas storm a while ago) so it's still valid.  a couple scenarios:
how does the vehicle know where the lanes are, if you can't see them?  people a lot of times can't and just drive where they think they are.
how does the lidar, cameras and other sensors deal with getting snow/mud packed into/on them?
how does the vehicle handle getting stuck or avoiding deeps snow or drifting snow?
muggings/robberies of the future (play ambulance sound, and our victims are now stuck and can no longer drive away). ez.
and what about construction areas where jumping painted lanes to stay in you lane is the normal?
or when you have multiple lines (old ones painted over) but in the rain in the dark the glossiness looks the same?
what about other crazy construction areas?
or storms pushing trees down, will it attempt to go into oncoming traffic if safe to go around it?  or will you be forever stuck until a developer shows up? and what if electricity (like an electrical pole) is involved?
as for weighing consequences, your supposed to run over bambi instead of going into oncoming traffics,  do the cars do this?
these are just a couple random thoughts i had while watching the video.

what about the scenario where a tire blows out, or a component fails  like a ball joint or even worse, engine/lithium batteries catches on fire? i guess better hope the emergency stop sticks around and people are smart enough to use it if needed.  kids will need to be trained on this. penalties for using emergency stop on big highway bridges when not needed.
so, yes, while i can see where the average autonomous cars is probably better then the average humans when the environment is in good conditions compared to humans being human.  i wonder how that really changes when the car is put outside its element?

i do feel more comfortable with autonomous operations where systems are more regulated in freedom of movement, and surrounding information.  ie: monorail is on a rail and can only go forward and back and the logic behind the rail is simpler to recognize something on it.  an elevator goes up and down with backup brakes.  both previous examples with sensors on doors which work for most scenarios,  you can find videos of dogs + elevators + leashes (autonomous overlooking the system) that are cringe to watch as well as recently that school girl that was stuck in the bus door as it was driving (human overlooking system).  as for planes, they have adsb in/out, radar, active ground monitoring, rules of what can be done in what airspace etc... which make autonomous much more successful with the only downside is making sure the whole industry is on the same page.  autonomous cars have a lot of surrounding environmental variables that make it leary.  im sure with time it can reasonably account for these, and that probably explains why people say 10yrs.  that and a lot of scenarios never get explained.  i would really like to see a video showing "what happens when" with autonomous vehicles in the scenarios i came up with and more.

so where is tesla standing in front (or back) of the waymo? is it already at level 4? i believe in tesla more than waymo. sure it does not have (or probably has) a lidar, radar, etc. to map the surroundings in 3d, but it certainly has so many cameras already which, with the help of ai and ml, can already solve the self driving problem completely in the very near future. we don't have lidar and radar but 2 eyes and i'm sure a vehicle can become 100% perfect with a bunch of cameras. no need for lidar, radar. we can pretty accurately map the surroundings with those cameras, microphones, gps, and transponders (that can let the cars communicate with each other). tesla can be way better & cooler. go elon musk!

this would be a great idea if it was a bussing service rather than an uber service. the fact that it can only carry 5 people means that it'll be more expensive and it'll take up more road space, which doesn't really solve any problems from a pedestrian point of view or for that matter, even a traffic point of view. pedestrians will cause a car to stop and it will ripple down onto the rest of the cars in the system.

a more accessible and much cheaper system of busses or even trains would benefit lower income families more and reduce traffic, not to mention reducing the carbon footprint because of fewer cars being on the road. furthermore, a larger series of bus lines is much easier to track than an entire city of self driving cars.

you could argue that self driving cars are better because they can bring you directly to your destination, but this wouldn't be a problem if we made cities and towns easier to navigate and all services within a wide radius were accessible from a single bus stop.

imagine how much more roadspace we would have if we had a huge system of free, accessible, and even self driving bus services. we can even still have individual self driving car services provided for people with disabilities that are too far from any bus stops. it would be so much safer and more efficient and probably a lot cheaper to just take cars off of the road rather than replacing regular cars with self driving cars. just visualize the difference between the entire warehouse of self driving cars vs a parking lot of busses that takes up less space but can transport the same amount of people.

the biggest issue with this suggested approach, however, would be breakdowns and security breaches. if a bus breaks down, everyone on that bus is being delayed, whereas if a car breaks down, only that one person is being affected depending on the circumstance. if a security breach happens on a single bus, that could spell danger for a very large number of people, but arguably a security breach on a single car could be just as bad.

this is where my fear of the self-driving aspect comes into play, since it is always possible that there is some person ready to cause trouble from the comfort of their own home, instead of having to use force to take control over a bus. think about what's easier to track and easier to prevent, an experienced hacker that found a hole in the self driving system's security or a guy going in a bus and stealing it.

despite all this, i think it's some great technology and an impressive feat that i'm excited to see the future of. to me, it just seems to be a more expensive and complicated solution to a more systemic problem that can be solved by improving the systems of transportation that we currently have in place.

rain, snow, ice, fog, flat tire, construction, engine issues, etc - it's the future but still has to be 10+ years out for the average consumer. great for southwestern us climates in good weather and known areas. should really replace trucks first...

ok, there are some weird statements in this video. like comparing traffic to elevators. isn't it obvious how incredibly more complex car traffic is?
airplanes have auto-pilot, yes, but have you ever been in a plane without pilot? there are even two pilots in a plane! and i will argue that the scenario of flying a plane is a lot easier to solve for a machine than handling traffic. auto-pilots in planes do not even use machine learning algorithms to predict any future event. machine learning and specifically deep learning which is used in most of autonomous driving systems, produces models which are inherently unpredictable. it might sometimes be hard to predict the behaviour of other human drivers but at least you can expect some basic human-like decisions, not with ai.
why do you assume driverless cars are safer than human controlled? there is definitely not enough data to make such a statement. i don't even say that it's not the case, but there is certainly no proof for this anywhere in waymo's publications (they even state that it is very hard to produce reliable statistics to back such a statement).
you say it is unethical to not replace all cars by autonomous vehicles because lives could be saved? according to the same logic it would be unethical to remove the driver from the autonomous vehicle, because you know what is even safer than a driverless vehicle? a driverless vehicle with a driver as 'backup system'. this is the only form in which autonomous driving should be allowed in my opinion.
 sorry, but i disagree with many things in this video and the comparisons are terrible. at least, you acknowledged that it is a sponsored video.

the 3 pedestrian accidents involved the waymo being completely stopped, and the pedestrian/bicyclist running into it. that's...so telling about human stupidity. but at that point blaming the waymo would be like blaming a house for a drunk driver crashing into it lol. they really have made some strides in safety though, i live where these run and worked with some former drivers who gave some of the dirt. the accidents involving waymos were almost always either due to the other driver hitting it (like running a red, or just plowing into it because they weren't watching traffic) or because the waymo driver (they still had a backup driver for a long time) screwing up. like the former driver said they had an incident where the waymo driver fell asleep and turned the wheel, deactivating the automation, and rolled the van (thankfully no passenger or other vehicles were involved). there was an incident where one disgruntled former employee tried to cause wrecks, pulling in front of the waymos and slamming his brakes, and eventually got one to hit him. but police investigated, found the video footage of the dozen+ other times he tried it and failed, and he ended up in jail for it. they really are surprisingly good now, worst case that's happened lately was a funny one where a youtuber who documents all his waymo rides had the car get stuck due to bad construction (they put the cones way too far apart, so the vehicle got confused as to whether the lane was open or closed), and then the support team back at headquarters screwed up in their instructions they pushed to the vehicle which made it worse. so even in that case, it still involved humans making decisions and screwing up. 
so the future of these cars involves a lot, such as proper maintenance of roads, and more uniform rules for construction companies doing road work because we have all seen some really crappy companies that can't put their barricades in place right, or leave lanes too small for most traffic, etc.
that is because it is not his camera, but the next generation autonomous youtuber that will one day replace obsolete derek.

there is a great book by scott meyer called run program, it's set in the near future and talks about how the different driverless cars have different "personalities" like bmws are more aggressive with over-taking and lane changes. i found that idea really interesting because it's not something i'd considered before, but of course he's right, even given the requirement to obey local traffic regulations, the different manufacturers will use different software with different algorithms, and if ai is used then even individual cars will learn different habits depending on where and what kind of driving they do most often. a car used to tearing down the autobahn will likely learn to behave quite differently to one that spends its life stuck in london traffic.

the future of transportation is in my opinion threefold: electric, autonomous and collective.

 electric is pretty self-explanatory, electric motors are just way more efficient than ice, you can produce carbon free electricity etc. the only problem was energy density, but as storage technology improves, so does the need to ice drop.

i am a big fan of automation and i get that a lot of people say "i would miss driving". that might be true, that you don't get people away from driving, but new generations won't be so attached to that task. the upsides are enorm, from spacial problems for parking and charging spots, to safety, inclusion of people with disability or simply a reliable, way for old people to have autonomy. it's coming no matter what.

i think the last part is also crucial, but might need more of a cultural change. here in germany, we have ~80 million people, with 40 million automobiles. these 40 million cars are only used for about 1 hour a day on average and when in use, they transport 1.5 people on average. that is seriously wasteful, but cars are a status symbol. as younger generation question traditional values and status symbol, i think car sharing becomes more and more popular. even if you don't want to sit with stranger in a car, not having your car stand around useless for >95% of the time is a game changer.

you make it sound like the reason that we don't have driverless cars everywhere is because people don't trust them. but that isn't the case. the reason is because they don't exist. sure, a taxi service, in a specific area, where the invester has money to spend on experimentally developed cars and employees to monitor and develop the system, it works. whether or not it is financially viable versus just hiring drivers is another thing. but being able to buy a car and command it to go anywhere, is a way more complicated issue and this is the reason why a lot of people think this is a long way into the future.

is there an analysis of how much more traffic there will be if kids and other non drivers are not constrained to a ride by their parents availability? there are a lot of ways to relate the risks, but as a parent i could see my vehicle being on the road a lot more at the request of my kids to visit a friend or go to a store, etc. same for the elderly. i would have loved this available to my grandmother to see her more.. if we don't define what success will look like we find ourselves in a different future that is somehow the same. if we use the numbers of deaths or the efficiency of traffic as a reason to move in this direction, but the amount of traffic increases also as a result of this tech and we end up with better routes that use traffic data and lower percentages of accidents but the trip takes the same time and the number of accidents is the same, then what is it we are doing? it baffles me that we choose to augment the driving of a car instead of reinventing the logistics of people and stuff. autonomous driving systems work so well on rail and in the air but struggle on bad, ill-defined roads. think about it, if we somehow had computers while we had horse led carriages autonomous driving would be even more difficult. 

the car has lasted too long and this solution adds to a congested/unsustainable system we currently have. also it adds problems. you didn't answer how the helmet vs non helmet rider scenario would play out, you just dismissed it as unlikely. how are these situations addressed? or what if these don't just yield to emergency vehicles but also to vip vehicles whose owner bought a platinum pass? these are subject to new laws in a way a population would not respond to. imagine an emissions goal could be met by reducing fuel consumption, but my (any single persons) particular route is impossible or unreasonable under those conditions. the car is just going to comply, regardless. 

also, as stated in your video, these are not ready for a world where drivers are 50-50 autonomous or a person. also what happens when there is a lot of lidar from many of these vehicles? what about adversarial devices that purposely mess with these systems? people use radar detectors, what if they install a device that will cause an autonomous vehicle to let them pass or cut in? what about the psychology where drivers know the system will avoid an accident at all costs so they become more aggressive, leading to an increase of person to person accidents when they miscalculate whether a vehicle is autonomous?

there are so many questions and this is amazing tech. i just think moving people and things the way we do is terrible and adding this to the mix isn't going to result in the positive future we can imagine or characterize with statistics.
